___ M presenting with atraumatic left hip and and low back pain

. 
Pt states that the pain is severe, ___. There is pain 
localized L hip region, which starts L anterior pelvis at 
midline, and wraps around pelvis to posterior L spine.  Pain 
worse with leg movement.  Sharp. Relieved somewhat with rest.  
Pt also notes history of bilateral leg pain, which starts at 
hips and radiates downt to feet B; does not have currently, and 
pt unable to describe if similar pain to hip pain, or if similar 
onset.  Pt does note that the leg pain improves when leaning 
over a shopping cart.  Pt is unclear if the hip pain improves 
with this as well, as he has been unable to ambulate.
.
Of note, multiple phone calls logged in on Epic.  ___, called 
complaining of shortness of breath as well as ? rib vs chest 
pain.  Earlier, called about hip pain.  ___, called about 
chalky feeling in throat and difficulty walking as well as cold 
extremities; was advised to suck on candy and push fluids. He 
was seen by PCP ___ ___ for hip pain.  The PCP noted that the 
pain might be due to decreased exercise and recommended that 
patient start to exercise more.  Hip film ordered but never 
performed.  
.
Pt also notes significant SOB, DOE, 3 pillow orthopnea (same as

weight is 274-275, and states more recently has been 285-286.  
He states he drinks "a lot of water", but has difficulty 
quatifying.  Estimated a little more than a liter, but this 
estimate is suspect.  States he reads labels, and eats low 
sodium, but does not add numbers to ensure <2gm/day.  He uses 
CPAP, but is not religious about it, and states he tries to use 
it for 6 hrs per night, but it is unclear if he is successful in 
this goal.

Pertinent Results:
CT L-spine (___):
1. No acute fx or malalignment of the L spine. 
2. A small pocket of air in the retroperitoneal space next to 
the spine at 
T11 (image 4:1), incompletely imaged and of uncertain etiology. 
Could 
represent vaccum gas phenomenon. Recommend clinical 
correlations.
RADIOLOGY ATTENDING ADDENDUM
There is some degree of spinal stenosis at L4-5. The severity is 
difficult to evaluate due to overlying artifacts, but it is 
potentially severe. This appears to be due to a combination of 
disk bulging, perhaps protrusion, and facet joint osteophytes. 
MR may be helpful if further evaluation is indicated. There is a 
small collection of gas in the spinal canal on the right, just 
below the L4-5 interspace. This suggests a disk protrusion in 
this location, atlhought there is not sufficient soft tissue 
contrast to fully evaluate it. There is bulging of the disk at 
L5-S1 without evidence of a protrusion. Again, image quality is 
limited and MR may be helpful. 
 
CT Pelvis (___):
1. Large L inguinal hernia, with a loop of bowel in the sac. No 
evidence of obstruction. 
2. bony pelvis noted with DJD, but no acute fx. 

Hip and L-spine X RAY ___: 
No acute fracture or dislocation. Please refer to the concurrent 

CT pelvis for additional findings of a large left inguinal 
hernia. 

Echo (___):
CONCLUSIONS
1. The left ventricle size is normal. There is mild concentric 
left ventricular hypertrophy. Overall left ventricular systolic 
function is low-normal, with an estimated LVEF of 50-55 %. There 
is septal flattening in systole which is consistent with right 
ventricular pressure overload.
2. The left atrium is moderately dilated.
3. The right ventricle is moderately enlarged.  The right 
ventricular systolic function is moderately impaired.
4. The right atrium is moderately dilated.
5. There is mild-to-moderate tricuspid regurgitation present. 
Estimated PA systolic pressure, calculated from peak TR 
velocity,  is 53 mmHg above RA pressure.
6. Compared with the findings of the prior study (images 
reviewed) of ___, right heart findings are worse. However, with 
retrospective review of the prior study (which has even more 
limited imaging of the rightheart than the present study), there 
is probably some early and mild abnormalities of the right 
heart.

___ ECHO 
The left atrium is moderately dilated. The right atrium is 
markedly dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular 
hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is considerable 
beat-to-beat variability of the left ventricular ejection 
fraction due to an irregular rhythm/premature beats. The right 
ventricular cavity is dilated with depressed free wall 
contractility. There is abnormal diastolic septal 
motion/position consistent with right ventricular volume 
overload. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and 
arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly 
thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic 
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral 
regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is 
normal. There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Atrial fibrillation making evaluation of ventricular 
function challenging. Mild symmetric left ventricular 
hypertrophy with preserved global and regional left ventricular 
systolic function. Dilated and hypokinetic right ventricle with 
evidence of volume overload.  

CHEST X RAY PA/LAT ___: 
Findings consistent with moderate pulmonary edema and small left 

pleural effusion in the setting of cardiomegaly. Recommend 
repeat radiograph after diuresis. 

CHEST X RAY AP PORTABLE ___: 
FINDINGS: In comparison with the study of ___, there is little 
overall 
change. Bibasilar atelectasis persists with enlargement of the 
cardiac 
silhouette in a patient with low lung volumes. Some left pleural 
effusion may well be present. However, no definite pulmonary 
edema is appreciated. 
Of incidental note is an azygos fissure, of no clinical 
significance.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o male who presented with atraumatic left hip, left low 
back, and occassional bilateral lower extremity pain worse with 
standing and without neurological symptoms likely due to spinal 
stenosis who was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia. 

Hypoxia / acute on chronic diastolic CHF:  Patient presented 
with a new oxygen requirement, satting 94% on 3L NC with 
bilateral rales on exam and a reported 10 lb weight gain over 
his dry weight with concern for pulmonary edema. CXR revealed 
moderate pulmonary edema and small left pleural effusion in the 
setting of cardiomegaly, BNP was > 3000. He ruled out for an MI, 
his repeat echocardiogram revealed a normal EF and mild LVH.  
The patient was initially doing well on the floor early in his 
admission. The patient was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia 
related to worsening pulmonary edema.  In addition the patient 
was diuresed and developed a contraction alkylosis, and he was 
treated with diamox to help correct this.  He was given 
agressive potassium repletion during diuresis and his potassium 
remained at 3.1 upon discharge.  He was discharged home at his 
dry weight of 175 lbs, had a room air O2 sat of 97% and a 
ambulatory O2 sat on room air of 91%.  He was ambulating well 
but will get home ___, and given his admission for heart failure 
he was referred for tele health to help with diuretic management 
should he gain greater than 3 pounds above his dry weight.  He 
was continued on his beta blocker and his home dose of lasix 
120mg po bid.  His obstructive sleep apnea is likely a dominant 
cause in his R heart failure related to moderate pulmonary 
hypertension and is treated with CPAP.

Back and Leg pain: CT demonstrated mild degenerative changes in 
the pelvis but no fractures.  He was noted to have spinal 
stenosis. Patient received Tylenol standing and Oxycodone PRN 
for breakthrough pain. ___ consult was also provided. Pain and 
mobility improved.  Given the improvement in his symptoms he was 
treated conservatively however an MRI of the spine is indicated 
as an outpatient to further assess for severity of spinal 
stenosis.

Obstructive sleep apnea: Patient was maintained on CPAP at 
night. 

Atrial Fibrillation: Patient was on Metoprolol for rate control 
and Warfarin for anti-coagulation at home. INR was therapeutic 
on admission, was down to 1.5 on discharge, he was given 7.5mg 
po x 1 on ___ then continued on 6.25mg po daily until his 
follow up on ___ with his PCP and warfarin dosing can be 
adjusted.  

Peripheral vascular disease: Patient was on Aspirin at home and 
was continued throughout hospitalization. 

Hypertension: Patient was continued on Metoprolol and Lasix. 

Coronary Artery Disease: Continued on Aspirin and Metoprolol per 
above. 

History of Melanoma and Squamous Cell Cancer: No known current 
recurrence.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have a right periprosthetic fracture and was admitted to the 
orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the 
operating room on the for ORIF right periprosthetic femur 
fracture, which the patient tolerated well. For full details of 
the procedure please see the separately dictated operative 
report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable 
condition. Her PACU course was notable for a prolonged stay due 
to inability to wean off phenylephrine which subsequently 
resolved with fluid resuscitation. The patient was initially 
given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a 
regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was 
given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per 
routine. The patient's home medications were continued 
throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who 
determined that discharge to rehab was appropriate. 

The medicine service was consulted for preoperative evaluation 
and continue to follow her after surgery.

Patient had anemia with hematocrits below 24 postoperatively, 
and was transfused several units per geriatrics protocol (1u 
pRBC on ___, 1u pRBC on ___, and 1u pRBC on ___. She had 
an appropriate and robust response in her hematocrit and 
remained hemodynamically stable with no evidence of bleeding on 
exam.

Some asymmetric lower extremity swelling was noted, right 
greater than left, and patient subsequently went for an 
ultrasound of her right lower extremity which showed no evidence 
of DVT.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
partial weightbearing in the right lower extremity, and will be 
discharged on Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will 
follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was 
had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected 
post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or 
return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The 
patient was also given written instructions concerning 
precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. 
The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
-Partial weightbearing right lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
  1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is 
an over the counter medication.
  2)  Add tramadol as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean off 
this medication in 1 week or sooner.  This is an example on how 
to wean down:
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
  3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.
  4)  Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of 
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must 
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot 
refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 
  5)  Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you 
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue 
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication 
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over 
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
  6)  Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
  7)  Please take all medications as prescribed by your 
physicians at discharge.
  8)  Continue all home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon.
      
ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Lovenox daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If 
draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper 
tape.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed.
- Do NOT get splint wet.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever ___ 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with your Orthopaedic Surgeon, Dr. ___. You 
will have follow up with ___, NP in the 
Orthopaedic Trauma Clinic 14 days post-operation for evaluation. 
Call ___ to schedule appointment upon discharge.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for any new medications/refills.

THIS PATIENT IS EXPECTED TO REQUIRE <30 DAYS OF REHAB
Physical Therapy:
Partial weight bearing
ROM as tolerated
Treatments Frequency:
Skin staples to be removed at 2-week follow-up
Dry sterile dressing may be applied if mild serosanguineous 
oozing is noted from the incision
Otherwise incision may be left open to air

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were hospitalized due to symptoms of left facial droop 
resulting from a transient ischemic attack, a condition in which 
a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is 
transiently blocked and causes symptoms. The brain is the part 
of your body that controls and directs all the other parts of 
your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived of its 
blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms.

TIA can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:
- hyperlipidemia (high cholesterol)
- high blood pressure
- atrial fibrillation

We are changing your medications as follows:
- START atorvastatin 20 mg daily 
- START fish oil supplements twice a day

Please take your other medications as prescribed. 
Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:
- sudden partial or complete loss of vision
- sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth
- sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you
- sudden weakness of one side of the body
- sudden drooping of one side of the face
- sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body
- sudden difficulty pronouncing words (slurring of speech)
- sudden blurring or doubling of vision
- sudden onset of vertigo (sensation of your environment 
spinning around you)
- sudden clumsiness of the arm and leg on one side or sudden 
tendency to fall to one side (left or right)
- sudden severe headache accompanied by the inability to stay 
awake
It was a pleasure providing you with care during this 
hospitalization.

Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.

developed rapid atrial fibrillation and recurrent flash 
pulmonary edema. She was found to have new severe MR and TR, 
without vegetations on the valves, and with dilated atria 
suggesting a chronic process. She was transfered to the 
cardiology service and then to medicine for management. She was 
in decompensated heart failure and diuresed with good effect.

If clinical suspicion for pulmonary embolism remains high,

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with ___ disease, CHF, HTN, recent bladder cancer 
resection (~1 week prior) who presents with jaw dislocation, 
subclavian vein thrombosis, hematuria.

# Jaw dislocation: 
Likely due to recent surgery and complication from anesthesia. 
She underwent reduction in the ED with apparent proper alignment 
per CT sinus. She is now tolerating modified diet without active 
aspiration (however, I am concerned about continued silent 
aspiration). She needs continued S+S evaluation.

# Subclavian vein DVT:
She was found to have subclavian vein DVT at OSH. She did not 
have a history of central catheter per patient/family. We 
attempted anticoagulation with heparin drip; however, this was 
complicated from hematuria with hematocrit drop. Anticoagulation 
was stopped as the risk of significant bleed was thought to 
outweigh the benefit of upper extremity DVT treatment. I 
discussed with patient and family and they agreed. If the 
hematuria resolved, anticoagulation can be considered in ___ 
weeks if clinically indicated.

# Hematuria, gross:
# Bladder mass:
This was likely due to recent surgical removal or bladder 
cancer. She had no visible hematuria after discontinuation of 
anticoagulation. She will need to follow up with urologist for 
results and further evaluation and management. After discussion 
with daughter (HCP), they would not opt for chemotherapy or 
other aggressive therapy at this point if continued malignancy. 
Cancer could explain some of her symptoms such as continued 
fatigue and anorexia. She will need to follow up with urology to 
determine final results of her bladder mass resection and to 
determine appropriate follow up therapy. Palliative care or 
hospice should be considered.

# Consolidation of chest CT:
This was likely due to aspiration. There was no evidence of 
active pneumonia based on WBC, O2 requirement, fevers, etc. She 
did have bibasilar crackles on exam. She was continued on 
levofloxacin (prescribed from prior bladder surgery) which was 
changed to Augmentin after she was noted to have achilles 
tendonitis. If she develops fevers, worsening SOB, etc, she may 
need HCAP treatment for likely aspiration pneumonia.

# Left achilles tenderness:
Likely due to fluoroquinolone. This was discontinued and she was 
started on Augmentin. Continue to work with ___.

# Deconditioning:
She has significant weakness. Likely from hospitalization and 
acute and chronic medical issues. She will need aggressive 
rehabilitation.

# Thyroid masses:
Discussed need to obtain ultrasound with family and letter sent 
to PCP. This will be pursued as outpatient if necessary.

# Hypernatremia: 
This resolved after encouragement of PO intake. In addition, 
lasix was held. This was held at time of discharge, but may need 
to be restarted if hypervolemic.

# ___ disease:
She ambulates with walker at baseline. Significantly weak 
currently. Continues on Sinemet.

# Anemia:
Microcytic. Presumably from bleed from urinary source. Needs 
close monitoring to make sure improves as outpatient.

Transitional issues:

- thyroid ultrasound as outpatient

- S+S evaluation for continued aspiration, ___ for chest ___
- treatment of malnutrition, consider trial of zinc supplement 
for lack of taste
- consider trial of anticoagulation in future
- labs in ___ days to ensure stability of CBC, electrolytes
- consider discussion of goals of care with focus on palliative

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is an ___ yo female with a pmh history significant 
for diabetes, hypertension, and depression who was seen at her

Active issues: 
#VIRAL PNEUMONIA: The overall story and clinical picture was 
felt to be concerning for heart failure. That said her BNP was 
wnl. There was no focal consolidations on her CXR, it is 
consistent with pulm edema. Influenza was ruled out with a 
negative flu swab. Other concerns include cardiac etiology, such 
as a missed event in this diabetic patient with a week of 
worsening symptoms, though her EKG is without signs of q-waves 
and trop is negative. Additional significant wheezing on exam 
was suggestive of possible bronchitis vs COPD like picture 
though she has never been formally diagnosed. She was diureses 
with IV lasix with some improvement. This was limited by both 
hypotension and acute renal failure.  ECHO was without evidence 
of systolic dysfunction.  She was also given nebulizer 
treatments. The patient initially improved and O2 was weaned. 
However on ___ shortness of breath became acutely worse 
with increasing O2 requirement.  CXR was unchanged.  She became 
increasingly less responsive over the course of the day. Vanc 
and zosyn were started for empiric coverage of a possible HAP.  
ABG demonstrated hypercarbia and she was intubated and 
transferred to the MICU. In the ICU the patient was treated for 
COPD exacerbation with steroids (though no documented history of 
COPD and is not a current/former smoker), she was treated for 
HCAP initially. She did very well and was extubated on ___ 
with improvement in her pCO2 to the ___ which appears to be 
patients baseline.  The ICU team suspects a component of obesity 
hyperventilation syndrome and OSA though this has never been 
formally diagnosed in the patient. CXR in the ICU showed no PNA 
but did show a possible interstitial process which would be 
consistent with a viral PNA. The patient has responded well to 
albuterol/ipratropium nebs. Antibiotics for HCAP were 
discontinued ___ with no change in patient's respiratory status. 
She completed a 5 day course of azithromycin. Steroids were 
tapered over a 9 day course (3 days remaining at time of 
discharge).

# HYPERCARBIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE: As above, she was intubated 
on the floor on ___ with profound ventilatory 
decompensation with a pH of 7.14 and pC02 104 after developing 
somnolence and encephalopathy earlier that morning.  CXR showed 
initially some increased interstitial marking, prompting concern 
for aspiration event (thick secretions were suctioned at the 
time of intubation), so vancomycin and zosyn were continued, in 
addition to azithromycin for atypical coverage.  She was given 
steroids as well due to wheezing  on exam. The cause of her 
decompensation remains somewhat unclear- the elevated 
bicarbonate and elevated venous pC02 on admission suggest a 
chronic hypoventilatory/hypoxemic disorder, and due to a lack of 
primary and secondary cigarette smoke exposure we suspect 
OSA/obesity hypoventilation syndrome particularly given her 
habitus.  We suspect that she began to retain C02 on the floor 
in her sleep due to hypoventilation which fed an encephalopathy 
possibly worsened by an aspiration event versus some pulmonary 
edema, which in turn suppressed her respiratory drive further. 
Her gas normalized quickly on CMV, though early trials of 
pressure support failed due to a complete lack of a respiratory 
drive.   As her encephalopathy waned, her respiratory drive 
improved. Due to a finding of some interstitial infiltrates on 
CXR, she was diuresed.  She was extubated successfully on ___ 
with in-tact mental status.  We stopped vancomycin and zosyn on 
___ due to lack of fevers or imaging evidence of pneumonia.  
Azithromycin was continued for a 5d course, and her steroids 
were tapered over 9 days (3 days left at discharge).

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___ year old morbidly obese male with a hx of DM, 
HTN, dyslipidemia, CAD presenting with decombensated heart 
failure and possible ACS vs. PE.
.
# CORONARIES: While the patient only reported a history of 
anginal pain, EKG with evidence of prior anteroseptal infarct. 
This would remain consistent with new finding of reduced EF to 
20% on recent TTE. He had no complaints of chest pain during 
admission, although he is a diabetic.  EKG was concerning for a 
STEMI, with elevation only limited to a single lead.  On 
transfer, given concern for ACS, pt was started on ASA, Plavix, 
heparin gtt and integrillin gtt.  Metoprolol was held due to 
relative hypotension. Given tachycardia, HF, previous treatment 
with dobutamine, flat CKs and mild elevations of troponins, he 
was felt to have demand ischemia in inferior region w/ an 
overlying possible remote anterolateral infarct during the prior 
month (as CP reported in HPI and Qw in V1-3).  Integrillin gtt 
was discontinued on ___, heparin and remainder of above 
regimen was continued.  Metoprolol 12.5 mg TID was started on 
___ for tachycardia and to increase time in diastole and 
reduce demand.  Pt was diuresed for HF (see below).  No further 
intervention taken and pt was continued on aspirin, statin and 
metoprolol.
.
# PUMP: Pt. presented w/ dyspnea at rest, JVD, and CXR 
consistent w/ CHF.  Precipitous events of decompensated HF were 
not clear, but a possible old anterolateral infarct ~ 1mo ago 
was a most likely possibility, along w/ a possible pulmonary 
infection given exudative effusion (see below).  TTE showed 
dilated and hypertrophied left ventricle with severe global 
systolic dysfunction, most c/w multivessel CAD, EF ___. 
Significant aortic stenosis. Moderate pulmonary hypertension.  
New TTE findings and q-waves on EKG were consistent w/ recent MI 
with worsening heart failure.  Patient was started on lasix gtt. 
 Given -1L on 15mg of lasix gtt, metolazone was started to aid 
diuresis.  Pt was diuresed 2 Liters per day while in hospital. 
Pt. dyspnea at rest resolved by ___.  He was continued on low 
dose metoprolol.  Subsequently the Lasix gtt and Metolazone were 
discontinued, and Torsemide 40mg daily with acetazolamide was 
begun. (pt had contraction alkalosis on labs).  He continue to 
diurese and alkalosis improved.  ACE inhibitor was held ___ low 
BP and could not tolerate the addition.
.
# RHYTHM/PE: Sinus tachycarida. Likely secondary to decopensated 
heart failure, hypoxia.  Pulmonary embolis could not be ruled 
out given impaired renal function and a nl CXR.  LENIs b/l were 
negative, but limited by body habitus.  Given high risk of this 
patient for PE, he was started on heparin gtt and transitioned 
to warfarin. Although ultimately it was not felt that the 
patient had a PE, he was continued on coumadin for prophylaxis 
given his body habitus and sedentary lifestyle.  
Tachycardia improved to 80-90s w/ low dose metoprolol.
.
# Pulmonary Effusion.  Based on OSH results, was consistent w/ 
exudative effusion w/ 5950 WBCs, 75% PMNs, 20K RBCs and LDH > 
200.  Cytology from OSH was negative for malignant cells, smear 
showed PMNs w/o organisms and Cx were negative. Patient 
developed low grade fevers to 100.2F.  These findings were felt 
to be most consistent w/ a parapneumonic effusion, and patient 
was started on a 5 day course of Levofloxacin which he 
completed.  PPD was placed to r/o TB given exudative nature of 
effusion and was negative.  All surveillence blood cultures were 
negative. 
.
# Diabetes.  Home glyburide was held and patient was started on 
lantus and sliding scale while.  Hbg a1c was 5.8 suggesting good 
control of DM.  He continued to require Lantus and did well on 
16U/day however will need this titrated down as pt recovers.
.
# Hypothyroidism.  TSH was 0.29.  Pt was continued on home dose 
of synthroid. 
.
# Anemia - Pt noted have have Hct 31 although baseline was 
unknown.  Iron studies drawn were consistent with anemia of 
chronic disease.  Folate was within normal limits and his B12 
level was borderline low.  No evidence of hemolysis on labs.  He 
did have a guiac positive stool.  He was supplemented with iron, 
b12 and folate and Hct improved to 32. 
.
# Prophylaxis - Pt was felt to be a high risk for PE, LENIs were 
negative. He was initially started on heparin gtt and bridged to 
coumadin

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___, 

You were admitted to the ___ 
for endovascular repair of your Left Iliac Artery Aneurysm. 

During your stay, your oxygen saturations were noted to be quite 
low especially when sleeping WITHOUT your CPAP.  When we woke 
you up, your oxygen levels returned to baseline.  At baseline 
your O2 sats where in the low 90's.  We agree with Dr. 
___ inhalers, including Advair and Spiriva, and home 
oxygen are indicated for your severe lung disease.   
Additionally it is imperative that you wear your CPAP nightly to 
prevent low oxygen levels.  

You tolerated this procedure well and are ready to return home 
to finish your recovery. 

Please see the following instructions regarding your discharge. 

MEDICATIONS:
 Take plavix(enteric coated) once daily for the next month 
only. 
 Do not stop  unless your Vascular Surgeon instructs you to do 
so. 
 Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
 You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort

WHAT TO EXPECT AT HOME:
It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your 
appetite will return with time 
 Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

ACTIVITIES:
 When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs
 You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry)
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
 After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
 After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate
 No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
 Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 
 Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
 New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
green drainage from incisions
 Bleeding from groin puncture site

FOR SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site or

pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call 
vascular office. If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for

1. Shortness of breath: Description of symptoms more consistent 
with paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea as it woke him from sleep and

exacerbation and has no oxygen requirement. He was dialyzed on 
the day of admission making volume overload less likely. CXR 
demonstrated a new infiltrate, and his asymmetric lung exam is 
consistent with a right lung process. He has had no fever and 
per his report, his cough is consistent with his chronic cough 
and the sputum is not new or different. He has slight leukopenia 
(day 11 post chemotherapy). He was started on levoquin/Vanco for 
his presumed pneumonia.  MI was ruled out with cardiac enzymes.  
He was also continued on his nebs and his cardiac medications as 
we felt heart failure could be contributing. 
.

patient tolerating PO.
.

extra session of ultrafiltration to make the patient more 
comfortable. We discontinued his PhosLo as his phosphorus was 
low. 
.

count at baseline, wbc slightly lower most likely due to 
infection. We trended his CBC which remained stable and he did 
not require any transfusions.

 Would consider rechecking LFTs to ensure complete

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___: 

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___.  You were admitted 
with nausea and chest pain.  You were found to have had a heart 
attack ("non-ST elevation MI").  This was felt to have been 
caused by stress on your body caused by a momentary blockage of 
your biliary ducts that resolved on its own.  You were seen by 
surgeons, who recommended against surgery right now.  You were 
seen by a cardiologist and underwent testing of your heart that 
did not show any concerning blockages.  You improved and are now 
ready for discharge home. 

Since your INR (Coumadin level) was high on admission, we have 
decreased your dose of Coumadin to 2.5mg daily.  It will be 
important for you to have your INR checked at your next visit.  

It will be important for you to follow up with your primary care 
doctor to have your blood pressure checked, and to discuss 
whether or not you should see a surgeon about having your 
gallbladder removed in the future.  It will be important for you 
to see your cardiologist.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is an ___ y/o man with a PMH of dementia, CAD 
(prior NSTEMI, type II), HTN, IDDM, hypothyroidism, BPH, recent 
admission to ___ for complicated UTI in ___ and admission 
to ___ in ___ for TURP and cystoscopy, who presents 
as a transfer from ___ with septic shock, respiratory 
failure, and ventricular tachyarrhythmia. 

# SEPTIC SHOCK
# COMPLICATED UTI. History of pan-sensitive Proteus and 
Enterobacter infections. History of Pseudomonas at ___. 
Given risk of Pseudomonas with history of insulin-dependent 
diabetes as well as current ___ plan to broadly cover 
with cefepime/vancomycin for now and follow blood/urine 
cultures. No evidence of pneumonia on CXR. Leukopenia consistent 
with severe sepsis. s/p 5L IV fluid resuscitation. Abdominal 
pain on presentation may have suggested an alternative 
intra-abdominal etiology such as enteritis or diverticulitis, 
although there is no history of bloody diarrhea to suggest this. 
If he fails to improve with antibiotics, would consider further 
imaging of abdomen/pelvis and adding on anaerobic coverage. The 
patient was continued on three pressor shock and his lactatic 
acid and acidosis was worse leading to worsening of blood 
pressures. Talking to the family regarding code status directed 
us to a DNR/DNI state. Also the family did not want to escalate 
care. There no additional pressors were added. The patient's 
blood pressure continuously dropped and suffered from a cardiac 
arrest and passed away on 4:10 AM. 

# RESPIRATORY FAILURE
# TOXIC, METABOLIC ENCEPHALOPATHY
# DEMENTIA
Respiratory failure secondary to obtundation and inability to 
protect airway. CXR without evidence of pneumonia or pulmonary 
edema. His encephalopathy may be secondary to sepsis on poor 
baseline mental substrate, however the most worrisome possible 
etiology would be intracranial hemorrhage given his history of 
falls. For now, will attempt to minimize sedation and obtain 
reliable exam and, if unable to do so, proceed with NCHCT. The 
patient was kept on minimal sedation. 

# POLYMORPHIC VENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA
# VENTRICULAR FIBRILLATION.
# ELEVATED TROPONIN. 
# CAD
s/p amiodarone 300 mg IV bolus, now on amiodarone IV load. 
Received external shocks x8 at ___ for polymorphic 
VT/VF. Suspect etiology may have been epinephrine boluses in the 
setting of septic shock, particularly given minimally elevated 
troponin (does have history of CAD and demand NSTEMI). Will 
evaluate for structural heart disease, monitor for signs of 
ischemia. No further tachyarrthymias here. Suspect elevated 
troponin secondary to cardiac trauma from defibrillation. The 
patient was given amio bolus and kept on a drip.

# ANION GAP METABOLIC ACIDOSIS. Unclear etiology; lactate 2.5, 
no ketones in urine; unlikely to represent co-ingestion. 
Differential also includes renal tubular acidosis, though 
relatively less likely. Will continue to monitor, fluid 
resuscitate, and correct academia. Acidosis deteriorate as his 
lactate worsened. His acidosis was not corrected with NaHCO3. 
The patient passed away due to worsening. 

CHRONIC ISSUES
# IDDM. Dose reduce home glargine + HISS and MIVF w/ dextrose.
# HTN. Hold home lisinopril.
# DEPRESSION. Continue home sertraline.
# HYPOTHYROIDISM. Continue home levothyroxine.
# BPH. Continue home tamsulosin.

___ presented to an outside hospital after 
becoming unresponsive at a restaurant with persistent 
unresponsiveness. There a CT head was concerning for R parietal 
subarachnoid blood and he was transferred to ___. She 
subsequently returned to her baseline, which was alert and quite

broad differential was considered, including seizure, syncope, 
stroke/TIA and psychogenic. Her workup was notable for: LP with 
bland CSF and negative cultures; CTA with atherosclerosis in the 
bilateral vertebral origins and carotid arteries without 
stenosis and LDL was 100; MRI which demonstrated small vessel 
disease but no acute stroke, acute or chronic hemorrhage, or 
evidence of metastasis; EEG which showed no seizures nor 
epileptiform discharges. On telemetry her QTc remained in the 
440-450s while on quetiapine and there was no evidence of 
arrhythmia. Her troponins were negative on admission. Her 
symptoms were thought to be most likely seizure vs. syncope and 
no treatment was started. Her home medications were continued 
and she was discharged home in stable condition.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

___ came to the hospital because of an episode of 
unresponsiveness. We think that ___ may have lost consciousness. 
We have looked for dangerous causes of this episode and have not 
found anything which needs intervention right now. We are not 
certain of the cause of this episode. 
 - It could have been caused by the heart and a temporary 
decrease in the blood going to the brain. We looked for any 
arrhythmias or any evidence of heart attack and did not see any.
 - It could have been caused by seizure, or abnormal electrical 
activity in the brain. We got an EEG which did not show any 
seizures. This does not rule out the possibility that she could 
have had one, but makes it less likely. 
 - It is very unlikely that this was due to a stroke or a 
transient ischemic attack. We did an MRI which showed no acute 
stroke. There was some evidence of chronic changes in the brain 
caused by high blood pressure and cholesterol.
 - Originally there was some concern for blood in the brain, 
also known as subarachnoid hemorrhage. However, the MRI (a more 
sensitive test) did not show any evidence of hemorrhage.

We have not made any changes to your medications. ___ should 
continue to take them as prescribed.

Please follow up with Neurology, your primary care, and your 
psychiatrist as outlined below.

It has been a pleasure taking care of ___.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
-Weightbearing as tolerated left lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
  1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is 
an over the counter medication.
  2)  Add oxycodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean 
off this medication in 1 week or sooner.  This is an example on 
how to wean down:
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
  3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.
  4)  Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of 
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must 
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot 
refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 
  5)  Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you 
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue 
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication 
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over 
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
  6)  Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
  7)  Please take all medications as prescribed by your 
physicians at discharge.
  8)  Continue all home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon.
      
ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Lovenox daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If 
draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper 
tape.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed.
- Do NOT get splint wet.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever ___ 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with your Orthopaedic Surgeon, Dr. ___. You 
will have follow up with ___, NP in the 
Orthopaedic Trauma Clinic 14 days post-operation for evaluation. 
Call ___ to schedule appointment upon discharge.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for any new medications/refills.

THIS PATIENT IS EXPECTED TO REQUIRE ___ DAYS OF REHAB
Physical Therapy:
Weightbearing as tolerated left lower extremity
No other activity or range of motion restrictions
Treatments Frequency:
Skin staples or sutures to be removed at 2-week follow-up

Brief Hospital Course:
___ h/o COPD, asthma, hypertension, and few months worsening 
pruritic xerosis presenting with dyspnea found to have volume 
overload, hyperkalemia and renal failure

# Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient presented with acute 
renal failure with creatinine of 2.2 (baseline ~1.0), likely 
contrast induced from a CT PE on the previous hospital 
admission. Her renal failure manifested with hyperkalemia, 
volume overload and subsequent respiratory distress. Due to 
volume overload, she was diuresed with IV medicines requiring 
metolazone as well as high dose IV furosemide. In the setting of 
diuresis, her creatinine uptrended due to pre-renal 
hypoperfusion up to 3.5. As such, diuresis was discontinued. The 
patient continued to make good urine on her own and maintain a 
constant weight. Upon discharge, her creatinine was downtrending 
and did not require medications for volume overload. Moving 
forward, she will likely require initiation of oral diuretics 
for what will likely become chronic renal failure. Furthermore, 
she will be followed by Nephrology with the possibility for 
dialysis planning as she required such high doses of IV diuresis 
in ___ to off load volume and potassium due to kidney 
dysfunction.

# Acute diastolic CHF: Patient presented with pulmonary edema 
requiring 3L of oxygen due to kidney failure as discussed above. 
An echo showed a preserved ejection fraction. She was diuresed 
with improvement of her dyspnea. Her discharge weight is 56 kg - 
there is no known dry weight for her. With this weight, she was 
able to maintain a saturation of 93% on room air. Diuresis was 
limited due to kidney injury. 

# COPD exacerbation: Patient presented with a clinical exam 
concerning for acute bronchoconstriction and hypoxemia. 
Pulmonary edema contributed to this picture. She completed a 
course of antibiotics as well as two prednisone bursts (5 days 
each) as her pulmonary exam remained poor throughout admission. 
She was treated with duel nebs and maintained on her home COPD 
medications. Pulmonary was consulted in ___ and recommended 
repeat CT scan and pulmonology follow up for both COPD and 
incidental findings on CT of unclear etiology and significance. 

# Multi-focal Bacterial pneumonia on CT: Patient clinically did 
not have signs of pneumonia but radiographic examination 
revealed multiple areas of consolidation. In discussion she with 
pulmonology she was treated with levofloxacin. However her 
course was cut short because of worsening kidney function in the 
setting of diuresis. The CT scan also suggested the possibility 
of Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare infection. Induced sputums 
could not be obtained in ___ due to logistical challenges. She 
will follow up with pulmonology for further workup. 

# Hyponatremia: Observed in the setting of diuresis so likely 
due to hypovolemia. If she continues to become hyponatremic can 
consider tightening her free water intake - 1500 cc from ___ cc 
in ___. Opted to not be aggressive in giving fluid in the 
setting of dCHF. 

# Presyncope: Patient felt light headed with blurry vision most 
likely related to over diuresis and uremic toxins. Her blood 
pressure was stable. No concern for seizure, new infection, 
neurological event, or arrhythmia. Her symptoms resolved with 
the cessation of diuresis. 

# Pleural effusion: Likely related to ___. Her history of 
weight loss and smoking history is concerning for malignancy, 
but there were no findings in the lung based upon CT. She will 
be followed by pulmonology and repeat CT scan for evaluation. 
Based upon CXR, these pleural effusion improved with diuresis.

# Hypertension: Blood pressure was high in ___. Her amlodipine 
was discontinued due to lower extremity swelling that confounded 
her clinical evaluation of volume status. Labetalol was 
initiated and uptitrated until appropriate blood pressure 
control.

# Hematuria: Traumatic Foley with aspirin and heparin 
prophylaxis. Spontaneously resolved.

# Hyperkalemia: patient presented with potassium observed in 
___ as high as 6.9. No ECG changes were observed. She was 
supported with calcium gluconate, insulin, Kayexalate and 
diuretics while her kidneys recovered. Prior to discharge, her 
potassium was normal. However in the setting of kidney disease 
and unclear prognosis, she will need lab checks for potassium 
and close follow up with nephrology.

# Chest pain: Likely related to anxiety and dyspnea. She was 
ruled out for ACS. 

# Leukocytosis: No localizing source of infection found in ___ 
and was likely related to steroid.

# Pruritis: Patient had several months of a pruritic xerotic 
rash on admission of unclear etiology. PET CT scan negative 
___ so likely no paraneoplastic cause. Rheumatology workup 
was negative; ___, anti-dsDNA, anti-Ro, and anti-La are 
negative. She was given hydroxyzine PRN with good effect.  

# Anemia: There was no evidence of active bleeding. MCV 108, 
suggestive of B12, folate deficiency vs marrow. Will defer 
workup to outpatient. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
========================
- Patient will need daily cardiopulmonary examination, 
measurement of input and output, weights, in order to monitor 
for volume overload due to CHF and kidney failure for the 
possibility of initiation diuretic therapy 
- Patient will also need chem 10 every 3 days to evaluate for 
electrolyte abnormalities in the setting of kidney failure until 
stable
- Full code

explained to the patient.  On the day of discharge her BP was 
under much better control, inthe 140/80 range.  The patient will 
follow up with her PCP regarding her hypertension.
.
2. Vertigo: The etiology may be elevated blood pressure versus 
benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.  The patients dizziness 
did seem to come on is she moved her head to quickly to the 
left.  The patient did not have any further episodes of vertigo 
after admission.  She will be discharged with a prescription for 
meclizine as was instructed to use it as needed for vertigo.

possibility of a stress test was discussed with patient.  She

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was brought to the Operating Room on ___ where 
the patient underwent CABG x 3 with Dr. ___.  Overall the 
patient tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was 
transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and 
invasive monitoring.  He required multiple blood products in the 
immediate post-op period.  He had VTac in the OR and was placed 
on Amiodarone.  Permanent Pacemaker was interrogated.
POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and 
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact 
and hemodynamically stable, weaned from inotropic and 
vasopressor support.  Beta blocker was initiated and the patient 
was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  The patient 
was transferred to the telemetry floor for further recovery.  He 
continued to have runs of VTac and was placed on PO Amio.  
Coumadin was also resumed for chronic AFib.  Chest tubes and 
pacing wires were discontinued without complication.  The 
patient was evaluated by the physical therapy service for 
assistance with strength and mobility.  By the time of discharge 
on POD 4 the patient was ambulating freely, the wound was 
healing and pain was controlled with oral analgesics.  The 
patient was discharged to LiveCare of the ___ in good 
condition with appropriate follow up instructions.

of breath. The patient was infused with 0.142 mg/kg/min of 
Persantine 
over 4 minutes. The patient denied any arm, neck, back, or chest 

discomfort throughout the procedure. Post-infusion, the patient 
did 
report nausea and mild lightheadedness which resolved following 
the 
administration of 125 mg aminophylline IV. In the presence of 
diffuse 
ST-T wave changes at baseline, no additional changes were noted. 

The rhythm was sinus with frequent isolated VPBs noted 
throughout the 
procedure with short runs of ventricular trigeminy. The 
hemodynamic 
response to the infusion was appropriate. 
  
IMPRESSION: Atypical persantine-induced symptoms in the absence 
of ECG 
changes from baseline. Ventricular ectopy as described. Nuclear 
report 
sent separately.

Brief Hospital Course:
SHORTNESS OF BREATH: the patient initially had a complaint of 
dyspnea on exertion which seemed to be crescendo and given his 
atypical symptoms which could have been anginal in nature and 
his high cardiac risk he was started on a heparin drip until he 
ruled out for MI.  Once he ruled out he was stressed with a 
p-MIBI which revealed an improvement in the mild reversible 
inferolateral defect he had prior to his last cath, no other 
abnormalities.  He also had an echo which was unchanged from ___ 
year ago.  He had an ultrasound of his L leg given assymetric 
edema which was negative.  His ambulatory O2 sat was 94% and he 
was never hypoxic throughout his stay.  His CXR was negative.  
Upon further discussion his shortness of breath seemed to 
improve.  It is unclear if increasing his lasix to 80mg po bid 
as the patient had done for 4 days prior to coming to the 
hospital is what aided in this relief or not.  He states that he 
has a fullness to his neck upon exertion so it was important to 
rule out cardiac ischemia for this but beyond that it is unclear 
what could be causing these symptoms, he does have tricuspid 
regur and perhaps this is giving him the sensation of venous 
congestion in his neck.

He also has a chronic cough and given his lymphoma it would be 
worth getting PFTs and a high resolution CT scan.  The patient 
will follow up with pulmonary at ___ along with PFTs as an 
outpatient.  This is scheduled for 1 week from discharge.  He 
was discharged on his home dose of lasix 80mg po daily.

CKD- stage IV, followed by ___, baseline Cr 2.8-3.1, 
within baseline.  Unclear etiology, perhaps due to 
hypereosinophilic syndrome (thought to have renal involvement 
but no known cardiac involvement in this patient)

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions: Please call your surgeon or return to 
the emergency department if you develop a fever greater than 
101.5, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, 
pain unrelieved by your pain medication, severe nausea or 
vomiting, severe abdominal bloating, inability to eat or drink, 
foul smelling or colorful drainage from your incisions, redness 
or swelling around your incisions, or any other symptoms which 
are concerning to you.

Diet: Stay on Stage III diet until your follow up appointment. 
Do not self advance
diet, do not drink out of a straw or chew gum.

Medication Instructions:
Resume your home medications, CRUSH ALL PILLS.
You will be starting some new medications:
1.  You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain 
from your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.
2. You should begin taking a chewable complete multivitamin with 
minerals. No gummy vitamins.
3. You will be taking Actigall 300 mg twice daily for 6 months. 
This medicine prevents you from having problems with your 
gallbladder.
4. You should take a stool softener, Colace, twice daily for 
constipation as needed, or until you resume a normal bowel 
pattern.
5. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
drugs) Examples are Ibuprofen, Motrin, Aleve, Nuprin and 
Naproxen. These agents will cause bleeding and ulcers in your 
digestive system.
6. Check your blood sugars 4 times a day and record.  Take the 
readings to your first appointment with Dr. ___ that he 
can decide if and when you should resume your insulin based on 
your readings and your diet.

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate
exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises.

Wound Care:
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 
If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old male with history of HTN, HL, a. fib on chronic 
anti-coagulation with BRBPR.
.
# BRBPR- The patient has a history of diverticular bleeding in 
___. He was initially admitted to ___ in 
___ with a Hct of 24.8 and INR of 1.5 and reports of BRBPR 
x wks. He was hemodynamically stable. He continued to pass clots 
per rectum and was transfused with 4U PRBCs and his INR was 
reversed. A tagged red cell scan was performed, which showed 
active bleeding. Surgery was consulted at the OSH and determined 
the patient was not a surgical candidate so the patient was 
transferred to ___ for ___ embolization. At ___, the patient 
continued to pass BRBPR (clots) and he was transfused an 
additional unit. ___ took the patient for possible embolization 
but did not see any active bleeding so no intervention was 
performed. GI was consulted and performed a colonoscopy which 
did not show any active areas of hemorrhage, but did show 
multiple polyps, diverticulosis, and possible ischemic colitis. 
GI recommended an outpatient colonoscopy. The patient remained 
hemodynamically stable with a stable hematocrit during his 
entire ___ admission. The patient was instructed to follow-up 
with his PCP for GI referral for colonoscopy. On the day of d/c, 
the patient's Hct was 27.1 with INR 1.4. 
.
# A. fib - The patient's home medication verapamil was stopped 
out of concern for GI bleeding and hypotension; metoprolol 50 mg 
TID was continued. On ___, the patient had an episode of Atrial 
fibrillation with RVR and required 10 mg IV Diltiazem pushed. He 
was started on 40 mg PO Verapamil TID. He was discharged on his 
home medication Verapamil 180 mg SR qd. The patient was 
instructed and the rehab facility was notified that he should 
restart coumadin on ___. The patient's daughter, also his 
health care proxy, was made aware of the risks and benefits of 
restarting anticoagulation. She expressed interest in speaking 
with the patient's PCP about the issue. 
.
# HTN- Anti-hypertensives were intially held but were restarted 
during the patient's admission. His pressures remained stable 
during the admission. 
.
# HL- The patient was continued on his home statin. 
.
# Recurrent UTIs - The patient has a history of recurrent UTIs 
associated with his chronic in-dwelling foley catheter, which he 
has had for ___ years. His foley was changed in the hospital and 
he reports it is changed at home each month. The patient was 
intially started on antibiotics at the OSH for his UTI but these 
were stopped because the patient was asymptomatic and there is 
concern for propagating resistant infections. 
.
#IDDM: The patient was kept on sliding scale insulin during this 
admission. His insulin requirements were much lower than his 
listed home doses of Lantus 16U qam, and 19U qpm. He was 
discharged on 10 U qpm but may require up-titration depending on 
his blood sugars. 
.
The patient was maintained on heparin SC BID for DVT 
prophylaxis. His code status was DNR/DNI. Communication was with 
the patient and his wife, daughter - his health care proxy, and 
son-in-law. Physical therapy worked with the patient and felt it 
was in his best interest to go to rehab to regain strength prior 
to going home.

Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___

Your blood pressure was never dangerously low, but you were 
transfused with 5 units of blood and your blood-thinning 
medication (Coumadin) was stopped and its effects were reversed.

You had a tagged red cell scan at ___, which 
indicated active bleeding and since it was felt that surgery was 
not in your best interest, you were transferred to ___ for 
further management. Here, our radiologists did a study and did 
not see evidence of active bleeding. Because you did continue to 
have lower GI bleeding w/ clots, our gastroenterology team was 
consulted; they performed a colonoscopy, which showed evidence 
of diverticulosis, multiple small colon polyps, and possible 
evidence of ischemic colitis. They recommended a repeat 
colonoscopy as an outpatient. Your red blood cell count remained 
stable during your entire admission at ___. 

On ___, you had a very fast heart rate due to your atrial 
fibrillation. You were placed back on your home medication 
verapamil and also received IV medication to help slow your 
heart rate. 

We made the following changes to your medications: 
We STOPPED coumadin due to your GI bleeding; further guidance 
regarding this medication is discussed below
We STOPPED Plaquenil as it was not clear whether you had an 
indication for this treatment and did not think you were taking 
this at home
We CHANGED your Lasix from 80 mg once per day to 40 mg once per 
day; you should weigh yourself daily and if your weight 
increases more than 3 lbs over 2 days, you may need to increase 
this dose back to 80 mg once per day
We CHANGED your Lantus dose from 16 U in the morning and 19U in 
the evening to 10 U in the evening- in addition to sliding scale 
insulin; depending on your blood sugar checks, your Lantus dose 
may need to be increased
We continued your Aspirin 81 mg each day, Ativan 0.5 mg each 
night as needed for sleep, Verapamil 180 mg SR each morning, 
Simvastatin 80 mg each day and Metoprolol 50 mg three times per 
day
We STOPPED your Novolog 
.

Because being on coumadin does increase your risk for GI bleeds,

Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman with history of follicular lymphoma, grade  II/III, 
recenntly d/c'd for allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell 
transplantation (day ___) who initially presented from clinic 
with diarrhea, orthopnea, and rash found to have E. Coli and VRE 
bacteremia, heart failure exacerbation, and altered mental 
status all of which resolved prior to discharge.

# Diastolic heart failure, Orthopnea, and Hypoxia:  
Patient presented with orthopnea and lower extremity edema 
concerning for diastolic heart failure exacerbation. BNP noted 
to be elevated. CXR and CT noted to have  pleural effusions with 
small pericardial effusion. V/Q scan obtained that ruled out PE. 
Patient diuresed with 40 mg IV lasix daily until euvolemic. 
Patient also received bilateral thorocentesis that was 
consistent with transudative process in setting of diastolic 
heart failure. Repeat TTE was obtained that showed small 
pericardial effusion though no tamponade physiology with normal 
EF. PO lasix 20 mg every other day was started prior to 
discharge. Patient noted to have 2L oxygen requirement 
throughout most of hospital course that improved to RA prior to 
discharge. The patient will follow up in cardiology clinic on 
___.

# Pleural Effusions, transudative in nature:
Patient noted to have bilateral pleural effusions that responded 
to some degree with diuresis. Patient also received bilateral 
thoracentesis for drainage. Thoracentesis studies were 
consistent with transudative process in setting of CHF above and 
did not show any evidence of infection or lymphoma. CTA chest 
obtained to rule out PE or pleural based process as etiology of 
effusions. Right upper lobe finding on CT chest thought to be 
consistent with pulmonary edema secondary to MR regurgitant jet. 
Patient followed closely by pulmonary as inpatient who suggested 
repeat CT chest with contrast in ___ weeks or sooner if clinical 
change occurs. Should there be persistent or worsened 
abnormalities on chest CT then patient should then be seen in 
general pulmonary clinic. Pulmonary also recommended repeat full 
PFTs (spirometry with bronchodilator testing, DLCO, lung 
volumes) when approaches euvolemic and stable. Also suggested 
follow-up in interventional pulmonary ___ clinic if 
re-accumulation of effusions.

# Complicated UTI: E. coli and VRE positive urine culture 
Patient noted to have E. Coli and VRE positive urine culture 
with resistance to ceftriaxone and cefepime. Patient was treated 
with Meropenem 1000 mg IV Q12H for gram negative and gram 
positive coverage as well as Daptomycin 250 mg IV Q24H for VRE 
coverage. Patient had left ureteral stent replaced during 
hospital course on ___ and as such meropenum and daptomycin 
were continued until one day post-op. She remained afebrile in 
the week prior to discharge following cessation of antibiotics.

#Follicular lymphoma, grade  II/III s/p allogeneic hematopoietic 
stem cell transplantation (day 65). CMV and EBV viral loads were 
monitored weekly. Patient was placed on prophylaxis with 
atovaquone, fluconazole, and valgancyclovir. Given anemia and 
thrombocytopenia patient had repeat peripheral smear chimerism 
study as well as bone marrow biopsy to evaluate the status of 
her graft. These studies were pending at time of discharge and 
should be followed up. The preliminary read for the bone marrow 
biopsy at time of discharge was not consistent with process that 
would require further hospitalization.

#Neutropenia
The patient was noted to be neutropenic on day of discharge with 
ANC of ~500. It was thought that this could be secondary to drug 
effect from buproprion vs. valgancyclovir. Neupogen was started 
on day of discharge to follow up counts in clinic on follow up 
and to consider repeat neupogen dosing as needed. In addition it 
was thought that buproprion could also gradually be tapered to 
eliminate its potential side effect of leukopenia.

# Poor PO intake/ Hypoalbumin: Patient noted to have poor PO 
intake and to be malnourished during hospital course. Nutrition 
followed patient and suggested calorie count with encouragement 
of 1500 calories/day. Her PO intake improved in the week prior 
to discharge. 

# Altered Mental Status: 
Patient noted to have altered mental status initially on 
admission and throughout first part of hospital course. MRI head 
obtained that was within normal limits. LP also obtained and was 
unrevealing. Some concern for cyclosporin toxicity and as such 
levels were closely monitored and adjusted accordingly. In 
addition doses of patient's gabapentin, oxycodone, and oxycontin 
were all decreased as well that was also thought to contribute 
to resolution of patient's altered mental status. These lower 
doses were continued at time of discharge. In addition patient's 
cyclosporin level was checked every ___ days and seemed to have 
no effect on patient's mental status when in the 200-215 range. 
Patient's mental status improved back to baseline prior to 
discahrge. 

# Acute Kidney Injury/ Left Hydronephrosis:
Patient with noted ___ on admission in setting of known 
hydronephrosis on left, which is where urethral stent is located 
(placed ___. Urology consulted who felt that 
replacement of stent was non-urgent but that it could be 
complicated when patient was optimized from volume status. Once 
patient was optimally diuresed she had replacement of her 
ureteral stent on ___ without complication. Perioperative 
meropenum and daptomycin were continued in setting of her known 
complicated UTI. Patient's renal function returned to normal in 
the weeks prior to discharge. Her operative report was requested 
to be sent to her ___ urologist Dr. ___ fax #: 
___. 

#Hematuria:
Patient has known hematuria that has been worked up as much as 
it can be given that she is post transplant. It was noted to 
resolve prior to discharge. Please follow up hematuria
 
# CMV viremia:
Patient noted to have CMV viremia. Viral loads were checked 
weekly and noted to downtrend and were undetectable on ___. 
Patient initially on gancyclovir IV dosing that was then 
transitioned to PO dosing of 450 mg twice daily. It was thought 
that valgancyclovir should be continued for 1 week following 
undetectable levels until ___. The patient was discharged 
with twice a day dosing to complete on ___. Repeat CMV 
viral load should be checked on ___ to ensure it remains 
undetectable.   
 
# Diarrhea: 
Mrs. ___ was noted to have 3 episodes of sudden onset diarrhea 
associated with fatigue on admission. Given proximity to allo 
stem cell transplant there was concern for acute GVHD. Other 
possible sources of diarrhea included CMV colitis, c. diff, and 
other bacterial infections as causative agents explored though 
all were negative (see results section, stool studies). Patient 
also noted that at baseline she had diarrhea and stool 
incontinence prior to hospital course secondary to pelvic 
radiation. 

# Rash: 
Patient presented with rash on legs that was concerning 
intitially for GVHD vs. rash of stasis. Rash noted to improve 
with diuresis and was thought to most likely be secondary to 
stasis. On ___ patient noted to have maculopapular rash on 
arms and legs without involvment of back or abdomen. Dermatology 
was consulted and felt patient's rash was most likely petichial 
in nature in setting of thrombocytopenia and did not biopsy. 
Rash was monitored with significant improvement in the days 
prior to discharge. As needed aquaphor was used with improvement 
of rash and continued on discharge. 
 
# Transaminitis
Patient with initial transaminitis in hepatocellular pattern. 
Initial concern for GVHD though thought to be less likely given 
normal bilirubin levels. Most likely cause of transaminitis waws 
thought to be possible drug effect. Transaminases were trended 
throughout hospital course and noted to be downtrending and 
returned within normal limit in the week prior to discharge. 

# Hypothyroidism:
Levothyroxine was continued

# Back pain: 
She has known pathologic fracture from likely prior lymphomatous 
involvement of L3 vertebral end plate. Evaluated by spine 
surgery prior to admission with plan for nonsurgical management. 
Back brace, oxycodone and oxycontin (decreased dose), as well as 
gabapentin continued throughout hospital course for pain 
control. 

# GERD: 
Pantoprazole continued throughout hospital course

# Depression:
Buproprion continued throughout hospital course.

Brief Hospital Course:
# UTI: Pt presented with Ecoli UTI that was resistant to Cipro. 
She was switched to Ceftriaxone and then should complete a 10day 
course of po Cefpodoxime. She remained afebrile in house with a 
stable WBC ct.  Plan to continue Cefpodoxime 200mg BID day for 
an additional 7 days to complete a 10 day course.
.  
# AF: Pt denies prior diagnosis of AF and this occurred in 
setting of acute illness.  However, given CHADs score of 4, pt 
will benefit from anti-coagulation for stroke prevention and she 
agreed to this treatment plan.  Pt was started on Coumadin and 
INR on day of discharge was 2.8. Recommend continuing Coumadin 
1mg daily with follow up INR to be drawn on ___.  Metoprolol 
was increased to 125mg BID for rate/BP control.
.
# Acute Systolic Heart failure:  Pt with depressed EF of 40% and 
2+MR presented with ARF and lasix was held, gentle IVF 
administered for 2 days.  Pt then began hypertensive with new 
oxygen requirement & bilateral effusions that had been seen on 
prior admissions.  Pt was gently diuresed with goal to wean from 
supplemental oxygen. Pt should continue Lasix 20mg daily with 
Lisinopril 20mg daily & increased Metoprolol 125mg BID. Please 
continue to tritrate lasix as needed until patient stable on 
room air.
.
# Hypertension: Pt developped poorly controlled BPs after lasix 
was held for 2 days and gentle IVF administration.  Suspect that 
rising BP was due to volume overload, after gentle diuresis and 
resuming home anti-hypertensive regimen, BP was much better 
controlled.  Pt should continue Lasix 20mg daily Lisinopril 20mg 
daily & increased Metoprolol 125mg BID.
.  
# CAD/Trop elevation: Pt had troponin leak after the episode of 
AFib with RVR and in the setting of UTI & ARF. Pt was noted to 
have some demand related EKG changes when in Afib with RVR but 
denied any symptoms. EKG was back at baseline after conversion 
to NSR. ECHO was unchanged from prior studies with depressed EF 
of 40%, MR & TR. Cards was curbsided due troponin peak of 0.31 
and they agreed that this was likely demand related troponin 
leak in setting of ARF. Pt likely has underlying CAD with flow 
limiting lesions, but pt clearly expressed goal to avoid any 
intervention including cath and the plan is for ongoing medical 
management of CAD.  Metoprolol was increased to 125mg BID and pt 
was continued on ASA, statin and Lisinopril.  
.  
# Acute renal failure: Pt presented with creatinine of 1.4 up 
from baseline of 0.9. Lasix & ACE were held and this resolved 
with gentle IVF. Pt was restarted on Lasix & ACE and creatinine 
remained stable at 1.1.
.  
# Anemia: Hematocrit was noted to have trended down from 38 to 
low ___ and iron studies revealed a Fe/TIBC ratio of <15%.  Pt 
was started on Ferrous Sulfate 325mg with bowel regimen. There 
was no report of guaic positive stools but recommend outpt GI 
follow up.
.

___ FDG TUMOR IMAGING (PET-CT)
1. Complete collapse of the right upper lobe with rightward 
mediastinal shift demonstrating FDG avidity and FDG avid

# Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
The patient presented with RUL collapse and mass c/f malignancy. 
Prior to admission she underwent thoracentesis on ___ which 
showed transudative pleural effusion. This admission, she 
underwent debulking and R mainstem stent placement with IP on 
___. IP procedure pathology showed squamous cell carcinoma. 
Radiation oncology was consulted who did not recommend 
palliative radiation at the time given the patient had underwent 
definitive treatment of her R mainstem obstruction with stent 
placement. She underwent further workup of her lung cancer with 
a PET-CT, which showed avid nodules in the L lung and adrenal 
gland. She had an MRI to evaluate the adrenal gland which was 
indeterminate as she was unable to hold her breath for an 
adequate study. She had a CT scan of the adrenal nodule which 
was consistent with a benign adenoma, but given the concerning 
findings on PET-CT it was not conclusive that this was a benign 
adrenal nodule. After discussion with Heme/Onc and IP, the 
adrenal nodule was biopsied by ___ without complication. 
Pathology was pending at time of discharge

# Hypoxemic respiratory failure
The patient suffered from hypoxemic respiratory failure due to 
RUL collapse secondary to obstructive mass with 95% occlusion of 
R main stem, with multifocal pneumonia also likely contributory. 
She was treated for her obstruction and pneumonia and 
respiratory status improved and she was transitioned to room 
air. On discharge, she had dyspnea with walks but ___ dyspnea at 
rest.

# Post-obstructive pneumonia
Per CT chest from OSH. She arrived from OSH on vancomycin and 
zosyn). She was narrowed to Zosyn as MRSA swab was negative. She 
was switched to ceftriaxone and metronidazole complete a 14-day 
course (___) for post-obstructive pneumonia per IP.

# Atrial fibrillation with RVR
CHADS-VASc = 4. 2D echo at CHA ___ with EF 45%, akinetic 
inferolateral wall and basal inferior wall, severely dilated LA. 
She was continued on heparin gtt I/s/o of procedures. Her atrial 
fibrillation w/ RVR was controlled with diltiazem gtt which was 
transitioned to fractionated metoprolol. However, she had poor 
control with her rates with metoprolol and so was transitioned 
to diltiazem with better control of her HR.

# ___ on CKD
Cr peaked at 1.7 at CHA from baseline 1.2-1.4, likely prerenal 
iso poor PO intake and infection. Resolved.

# Transaminitis
She had a mild transaminitis on admission which improved, alk 
phos persistently elevated.

abnormalities and inferolateral wall is akinetic with EF that 
had decreased from 60% to 45%. She was initially put on BB for

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o female with h.o asthma, afib on coumadin, who presented 
with fatigue, weakness, dyspnea and cough, was found to have 
extensive wheezing c/w an acute asthma exacerbation in the 
setting of a probable viral infection.  
.  
.  
#Viral bronchitis with acute asthma exacerbation-
Pt reports a h.o asthma and CHF. However, her clinical history 
of sore throat, cough and generalized weakness was suggestive of 
an infectious process. She reported T to 100 at home, but was 
afebrile without a leukocytosis throughout her hospitalization. 
CXR final read was negative for pneumonia.
She was initially treated with Levofloxacin, albuterol, 
atrovent, and steroids.  There was initially some concern that 
the patient may have an underlying pneumonia, however after 
further evaluation, this was thought less likely, and 
antibiotics were discontinued.  She was treated with scheduled 
albuterol/Ipratropium nebulizers with symptomatic benefit.  As 
she continued to improve, the frequency was decreased, and later 
changed to a scheduled Combivent MDI.  Her prednisone was 
started at 60 mg, however this was rapidly tapered down to 20 mg 
(and levofloxacin was discontinued), when she began to develop 
bilateral calf pain with ambulation that was concerning for an 
___ tendinopathy.  She was continued on her home accolate. 
 
Her BNP was elevated on admission, but her presentation was not 
thought represent acute CHF given her euvolmic appearance. 
Additionally, she was trialed with a single dose of IV lasix, 
which did not improve her respiratory status, but did cause a 
slight elevation in her BUN/Cr.
At the time of discharge, she was satting approx 94% on room 
air, but she required 2 L NC with ambulation for desaturations 
to 85%.  Her lung exam at discharge is notable for diffuse 
wheezing, with fair to good air exchange; this is significantly 
improved from admission.
Please note that the patient is on Advair BID at home. This is 
currently being held due to the acute exacerbation, but it 
should be resumed once the acute flare has resolved.
.  
#history of CHF-unknown EF. 
Pt has a known history of CHF, and she was recently hospitalized 
for a CHF exacerbation at another hospital prior to admission. 
She did not appear to be in CHF during this admission, despite 
an elevated BNP on admission. She was trialed with a single dose 
of IV lasix during the admission, which resulted in a slight 
increase in her BUN/Cr, suggesting that she is not volume 
overloaded.  She was continued on her home dose of lasix.
.  
# ___ tendonitis  
Pt was noted to develop bilat calf pain with ambulation with ___ 
on ___. ___ was negative for DVT. Pt is slightly tender to 
palpation at area of insertion of tendon to calf muscle. Pt at 
risk for ___ tendonitis given age, steroids, and 
levofloxacin.  Levofloxacin was immediately discontinued, and 
prednisone was rapidly tapered.  Pt's activity was restricted to 
levels that minimized calf discomfort, to minimize the strain 
and risk for tendon rupture.  At the time of discharge, pt 
reports that the pain has been improving, and is only rated as 
"very mild".
.  
#atrial fibrillation.  
No longer on coumadin per patient.  
-continued verapamil 240mg daily  
-continued asa 325mg  
- digoxin was resumed at discharge. 
.  
.  
#Dementia-continued aricept, namenda  
.  
#depression- continued Celexa 20 mg Tab Oral daily  
.  
.

.

bronchodialators and oxygen.
