Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You came to ___ from another hospital. There, you were having 
chest pain and underwent a cardiac catheterization. You were 
found to have blockages that were difficult to fix and 
transferred to ___ for further care.

Here, you were noticed to have very fast and irregular heart 
rates (Atrial Fibrillation). For the fast heart rate, we 
attempted to shock (cardiovert) your heart into a normal rhythm. 
Your heart went back to an irregular rhythm, so we treated you 
with medications to slow the heart rate down.

The fast and irregular heart rate also made fluid back up in 
your lungs, called heart failure. You received medications to 
help you get back into balance.

The irregular heart rate (atrial fibrillation) puts you at risk 
for developing blood clots and having a stroke. To reduce this 
risk, we treated you with a medication called Coumadin (generic: 
warfarin). This medication increases your risk of bleeding. You 
need to have regular blood draws to check your clotting levels 
while we get to a stable Coumadin dose. You can have these labs 
checked by the ___.

You should follow-up with your ___ doctors about the ___ 
results and treatment. Please also follow up with Dr. ___ 
(___) in 1 month for a repeat cardiac catheterization and 
possible cardioversion.

All of your conditions are stable and you are safe to go home, 
with follow-up at the ___.

We wish you the best!
Your ___ Team

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your recent 
admission to the ___. You came 
into the hospital because of cough and shortness of breath. We 
found that you had a fast heart rate as well as extra fluid in 
your legs and in your lungs from a heart failure exacerbation. 
An ultrasound of your heart showed that it is pumping with 
normal function but doesnt fill as well as normal. We treated 
your heart failure with a "water pill" called lasix. You will 
continue to take this medication, 60mg, daily. You will also 
need to take potassium supplementation (20mEq) daily as the 
water pill can cause your potassium to be low.

Please weigh yourself everyday and call your doctor if your 
weight goes up by 3 pounds or more.

We treated your heart rate with your home medication metoprolol 
and switched to a long acting form so you will take 1 of the new 
pill daily to control your heart rate.  Please follow up with 
your outpatient primary care physician and cardiologist as 
detailed below.

We also have treated you for a viral upper respiratory tract 
infection with a nasal steroid. 

If you should develop chest pain, palpitations, shortness of 
breath, fever, chills, lightheadedness please call your primary 
care physician or report to the emergency department.

Be well and take care.

Sincerely,

Your ___ Care Team

ACUTE CARE: 
1. Urinary tract infection: Patient developed altered mental 
status suddenly on the afternoon of admission after what is 
described to be rigors. ___ was symptomatic with suprapubic 
tenderness, weakness, and inability to communicate. His 
neurologic exam, as much as ___ was able to cooperate at the time 
is nonfocal. His catheter was changed, and with antibiotics 
ovenight his mental status improved and ___ was transferred from 
the ICU to medical floor. ___ again transiently spiked a fever on 
transfer to the floor but remained mentating well and then 
defervesced. ___ had a positive UA and a UC which grew mixed 
flora. ___ received antibiotic treatment with great improvement 
and was discharged home on a course of levofloxacin.
.
2. Hypoxia: Patient developed new oxygen requirement on 
transition to floor from the ICU. CXR showed vascular 
congestion. His home lasix which was temporarily held was 
restarted, patient had excellent urine output and his hypoxia 
improved. ___ was discharged on home lasix and satting well on 
room air.
. 
3. Acute Diastolic Heart Failure: On transfer to the floor from 
MICU, patient's chest exam revealed rapid onset rales and his 
oxygen saturation dropped from 98%RA to 94%RA. CXR revealed 
increased left pleural effusion and increased pulmonary vascular 
congestion. With resuming lasix therapy, patient had a 
successful diuresis and his oxygenation improved to no oxygen 
requirement. Echo revealed normal EF, showing this was likely an 
episode of acute diastolic heart failure.
.
4. Delirium: On presentation, patient was only responsive to 
questioning with grunts while his baseline mental status is 
A+Ox3 and capable of organizing club activities with groups at 
his living facility. This was likely secondary to infectious 
process on top of underlying mild chronic cerebral vascular 
disease. The altered mental status resolved with IV antibiotics 
and patient returned to his baseline mental status with 
treatment of UTI.  
.

She was admitted ___ to ___ for L5-S1 fusion that was 
uncomplicated.  She was not discharged on DVT prophylaxis given 
the surgery.  She was at rehab until about 1 week ago.  This 
morning, she complained of palpitations as well as leg pain 
which was new.  Then her physical therapist noted a low BP 
(unclear reading) and felt that she may be dehydrated.  She also 
complained of chest pain.  Later, her ___ noted low BP as well.  
Her daughter then witnessed a tonic-clonic seizure where the 
patient fell back on the bed and her eyes rolled back in her 
head and her extremities were shaking.  She has never had 
seizures prior.  EMS was called.  BP on arrival by EMS was 
60/palp which improved to 74/palp after 500cc IVF.

In the ED, she was hypotensive and initially given aspirin and 
morphine.  CTA showed massive saddle PE.  She was hypotensive 
with SBP in the 30___s and was intubated and started on peripheral 
levophed.  Also given 6L fluid.  TPA was then initiated at 21:39 
(100mg IV over 20 minutes).  Sedated with versed and fentanyl.

decreased to the 50's and she lost a pulse and chest 
compressions were started, 1mg epi given, pulse returned after 1 
minute.  Cardiology was consulted but declined to take her to 
the cath lab.  Her BP's began to improve and SBP was 170's and 
pressors were weaned.  Currently SBP in the 90's on 
neosynephrine only, HR 90's (previously 140-150).  Thoracic 
surgery also aware and discussing patient's case.  She then 
received 5000unit heparin bolus plus started on heparin drip at

Brief Hospital Course:
*Anticipated stay at rehab facility is less than 30 days.*
.
___ year old female with h/o HIV on HAART (CD4 1049) and recent 
L5-S1 fusion 3 weeks prior to admission who presented with 
hypotension and experienced cardiac arrest while in the ED, 
found to have massive PE.
.
# Massive PE with hypotension/shock: PE occurred in post-op 
setting. Received TPA in the ED with some improvement in 
hemodynamics but then became pulseless. She was coded in the ED 
with return of pulse. She was initially on pressors but was then 
able to be weaned off in the MICU.  Also had some demand 
ischemia with elevated cardiac enzymes that trended down 
afterwards. TTE showed global RV dilation/disfunction and severe 
TR w/ preserved LVEF. She was initially treated with IV heparin 
and was starting to be bridged to warfarin therapy. Prior to 
discharge, the heparin drip was discontinued, and the patient 
was started on Lovenox ___ subcuntaneously every 12 hours 
daily. The Lovenox was discontinued when her INR was 
therapeutic. She was discharged on warfarin 3mg orally daily. 
Her INR on day of discharge was 2.4. She will need to be set up 
with ___ clinic as an outpatient for INR monitoring. 
.  
# Hypoxia/Tachypnea: Patient successfully extubated ___ and 
upon arrival to the medicine floor was tachypnic breathing in 
the high ___, low ___ with 3 liters of supplemental oxygen. She 
remained stable, and on day of discharge, the oxygen was weaned 
with a respiratory rate in the ___. 
.
#Altered Mental Status: There was concern during the admission 
on the medicine floor that the patient had acutely developed 
altered mental status. Her neurological exam was non-focal and 
consistent with her exam on presentation to the medicine floor. 
Despite being afebrile without a leukocytosis, an infectios 
work-up was repeated. So far, this work-up has returned 
negative.   
.
# Anemia: Hct had trended down from 29 on admission to 25 at 
present. An active type and screen was maintained through the 
entire admission. She required no trasnfusions. She remains 
hemodynamically stable, with no evidence of active bleeding at 
present. She did have some mild oozing from OGT while in ICU, 
and she was started on ranitidine out of concern for GI bleed. 
Propton pump inhibitor was contraindicated given the iteraction 
with nelfinavir (part of HARRT regimen). 
.  
# Transaminitis: During the admission, AST as high as 2000s and 
ALT in 700s. While the patient does have h/o HBV and HCV, acute 
rise was likely secondary to shock liver versus hepatic 
congestion in setting of severe RV failure. His LFTs were 
trended through the admission and steadily fell during the 
admission. 
.  
# Elevated troponin: Trop peaked at 1.11 and has since trended 
down.  
Elevation was in setting of massive PE, shock, right heart 
strain and delivery of chest compressions. TTE showed dilated RV 
with severe systolic dysfunction. MB remained flat. 
.
#Idioventricular rhythm: The patient was monitored on telemetry 
through her admission. She remained mostly in sinus rhythm 
during her hospitalization, but she was noted to have times of 
broad QRS complexes without preceding P waves. These telemetry 
findings were confirmed on EKG. Cardiac enzymes were cycled and 
were flat. Cardiology was consulted and felt her rhythm was from 
an irritable focus secondary to her ventricular remodeling in 
the presence of her massive pulmonary embolism.  Cardiology 
recommended that the patient's metoprolol be stopped. Her 
metoprolol was discontinued.
.  
# Complicated Urinary Tract Infection: Patient with fever of 
100.4 on day prior to admission to the medicine floor. Through 
her admission on the medicine floor, the patient remained 
afebrile. Fever may be secondary to PE, liver dysfunction. No 
clear source of infection, as no consolidation on recent CXR; 
blood cultures remain negative to date. No leukocytosis. On day 
of discharge, the patient's urine culture returned showing 
enterococcus in the urine susceptible to ampicillin, macrobid, 
and vancomycin. She was started on Macrobid. Unable to give 
ampicillin secondary to the patient's penicillin allergy. She 
will be continued on Macrobid for a total of 14 days, stop date 
___. The patient will need to have a repeat urine analysis 
on ___ to determine if the patient is still infected. If her 
urine analysis returns suggestive of urinary tract infection, 
send a urine culture and consider starting the patient on 
vancomycin. If her urine analysis is sterile, complete the full 
14-day course of antibiotics. 
.
# Recent L4-S1 spinal surgery: No acute surgical issues at 
present. Ortho was followed the patient and recommended that her 
hematocrit be monitored given her recent surgery and TPA 
administration.   
.  
# Seizure: Patient reportedly had tonic-clonic seizure at home 
prior to arrival. ___ have been secondary to hypoxia veresus 
acidosis from massive PE and shock. No evidence of seizure 
activity this admission, and no prior history of seizure. 
Infectious work-up negative to date, with negative urine 
culture, no PNA on CXR, and blood cultures negative to date.   
.  
# Constipation: Aggressive bowel regimen with colace, senna, 
miralax and bisacodyl.  
.  
# Pain control: Patient had pleuritic chest pain secondary to

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization 
at ___. You were hospitalized 
because of a massive Pulmonary Embolism (a large blood clot in 
your lungs).  This blood clot likely came after your surgery, 
and formed in your legs then traveled to your lungs.  You were 
given medications to thin your blood, and will continue 
treatment for at least 6 more months.
.
You have been started on a medication called warfarin (AKA 
Coumadin).  This medication thins your blood.  The effects of 
this medication are checked with a blood test called the 
international normalized ratio (AKA INR).  Your INR is a number 
that reflects the "thinness" of your blood, and the goal INR for 
your treatment is between ___.  Your INR will need to be checked 
frequently in the beginning of your treatment ___ times a 
week), and will gradually be checked less ___ times a month) as 
your medical team helps adjust your medication to keep your INR 
between ___.  You should anticipate occassional warfarin dose 
adjustments (maybe more in the beginning), in order to keep your 
INR in the ___ range.  Warfarin metabolism is affected by the 
foods you eat, specifically leafy green vegetables.  You can eat 
the same foods you usually eat, but avoid drastically changing 
your diet and speak with your physician before changing your 
diet as your warfarin dose may need to be adjusted.  While on 
warfarin, you are at increased risk of bleeding.  If you notice 
severe bleeding, including rectal bleeds, bleeding from the 
urethra, or nosebleeds, contact your physician.  It is important 
that if you suffer a fall or traumatic injury while taking 
warfarin that you call your doctor or report to the emergency 
room for evaluation to make sure you are not bleeding 
internally.
.
Please take all medications as instructed. Please note the

You were transferred to ___ because you were 
found to have congestive heart failure. You had an 
echocardiogram which showed decreased pumping function as a 
result of damage to the heart muscle. You also had a slight 
increase in a blood marker that is used to test for heart muscle 
damage. This means you have suffered some strain on your heart. 
Much of this was likely a result of decreased pumping that 
caused back up of fluids causing your shortness of breath. You 
were aggressively diuresed with lasix to remove the extra 
fluids.

You also had a cardiac catheterization which showed 30% blockage 
in your left mainstem artery and 80% blockage in your left 
circumflex artery effectively decrease the blood supply to your 
heart muscle. The resulting plan was to proceed to CABG 
operation to by-pass these arteries.

Unfortunately, your kidney function was also slightly abnormal 
and, while waiting for it to improve, you developed a pneumonia. 
Because you had been in the hospital for several days prior to 
developing the pneumonia, it needed to be treated as per a 
hospital-acquired pneumonia protocol. Since your kidney function 
looks improved but you need a 7 day course of antibiotics for 
your pneumonia, you are going to an extended care facility prior 
to your CABG.

You have a follow up appointment with Dr. ___. You will 
address rescheduling your CABG at that time. You should also 
have blood work done prior to this appointment.

Please call alert the healthcare staff of your extended care 
facility if you have worsening swelling in your arms, legs or 
abdomen, shortness of breath, chest pain, pressure, or 
tightness, nausea, fever, chills, difficulty laying flat or 
waking up short of breath or any other concerning symptoms.

Brief Hospital Course:
Medicine Course
Acute systolic CHF: The patient presented from his cardiac 
rehabilitation facility with dyspnea on exertion. He was found 
to have an elevated BNP on evaluation, and his respiratory 
status improved following administration of 40mg lasix in the 
OSH ED. He additionally relates a history of orthopnea and 
recent increase in lower extremity edema, leading to suspicion 
for volume overload in the setting of heart failure as the cause 
for his dyspnea. There is no evidence of a suddent right sided 
event such as a PE based on the CTA. Abdominal and Pelvic CTA 
showed 4.6 x 3.1 cm fluid collection adjacent to the left common 
femoral vessels, which may represent a prior hematoma. The study 
was not tailored for evaluation for active bleeding, but the 
fluid in this collection is low density without evidence for 
extravasation of contrast. There is no evidence of an acute MI 
by troponin. The patient's most recent echocardiogram, s/p AVR, 
noted a depressed EF of 40-45%, however, a TTE done on admission 
showed a normal preserved EF. Cardiology was consulted, who felt 
that the patient's presentation was consistent with acute CHF, 
and the patient was started on BID lasix with strict I/Os and 
volume restriction. 

Sternotomy Wound Abscess: the patient was evaluated by plastic 
surgery, who elected not to remove his JP drain on ___ as 
previously scheduled due to the interval increase in size of 
fluid collection on CT scan. The JP drain will be removed by 
plastic surgery in ___ weeks as an outpatient. The patient was 
continued on nafcillin for MSSA coverage on admission. 

Atrial Fibrillation: the patient was noted to be in sinus rhythm 
on admission. He was continued on his home amiodarone and 
metoprolol regimen. His INRs were 2.2 and 2.1 on admission, and 
he was continued on his warfarin regimen with goal INR ___. 
Frank hematuria: the patient presented with frank hematuria due 
to traumatic foley placement at the OSH before transfer to 
___. He has a history of BPH but did not recently have any 
urinary retention. His foley catheter was removed on hospital 
day 1 and he passed his voiding trial, with rapid clearing of 
the hematuria.
 
Peripheral Neuropathy: the patient was continued on his home 
regimen of gabapenin, lidocaine, and tramadol on admission. 

On HD3, he was transferred to the cardiac service.  He was 
transfused 1 unit PRBC for Hct 27.7, which increased to 28.6.  
He was continued on Coumadin for Atrial fibrillation with a 
therapeutic INR.  He was diuresed with Lasix BID + Zaroxyln with 
improvement of shortness of breath. CXR showed small bilateral 
pleural effusions.  Plastic surgery was re-consulted to evaluate 
possibility of discontinuing the JP drain but the drains are to 
remain in place until his follow up appointment with Dr. ___. 
By HD 5, he was ambulating in the hallways with a walker, 
tolerating a full po diet, his hematocrit was stable, and his 
edema had decreased. He is to continue with Nafcillin for a 6 
week course via PICC for MSSA bacteremia.  He is to remain on 
Lasix po for peripheral edema and diastolic heart failure until 
follow up visit with Dr ___. It was felt he was safe for 
tranfer to ___ rehab at this time.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Red Surgery for management of her 
SBO and abdominal pain.  The patient was initially managed 
conservatively with NGT decompression and NPO status.  The 
patient continued on TPN as she was on at home.  The patient 
failed conservative management, so the decision was made to take 
the patient to the operating room.  On ___, the patient 
underwent a laparotomy, lysis of adhesion, enterocolostomy,small 
bowel biopsy.  The patient tolerated the procedure well with no 
complications and an EBL of 100cc.  For further detail of the 
procedure please refer to the operative note.  Post operatively, 
the patient was hypotensive and started on a Neo drip, and she 
was then transfered to the TICU for further care.  On POD 2 the 
patient was febrile to 103.8 and weaned off neo.  On ___, her 
PICC was removed and TLC placed. GPC's were found in blood so 
Vanco was started.  On ___, she developed new AF w/RVR, was 
started on a dilt/lasix gtt, and an ECHO done was normal.  
Furthermore, her Ucx was positive w/Ecoli so she was started on 
cipro and later changed to Gent ___ fluoroquinolone resistance. 
On ___ the patient was transfered to the floor in fair 
condition and rate controlled.  The patient's discharge was 
delayed secondary to physical therapy concerns about the 
patient's independence status.  Furthermore, secondary to the 
patient's poor po intake, TPN was continued.  On ___ the 
patient spiked a temp to 101.5 and the CVL was d/c'd and the 
patient maintained on D10W until PICC could be placed.  On ___, 
the patient self d/c'd her PICC accidentally.  On ___ a PICC 
was replaced via ___ without complication.  Upon discharge, the 
patient was afebrile with all vitals stable other than O2 
saturation, ambulating on O2 independently, tolerating po feeds 
but still on TPN, and with pain controlled on po pain 
medication.

Physical therapy was consulted to help rehabilitate the patient. 
 The patient progressed well with physical therapy, but the 
ultimate decision was made to d/c the patient home with oxygen 
___ desaturations to the mid 80's on ambulation.  

The spiculated lung mass found on CT was refered to 
interventional pulmonology for work up and management.  The 
patient will be managed as an outpatient and will be discussed 
in ___ clinic.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, 
gastroesophogeal reflux, and a 45 pack-year smoking history who 
presented with an episode of lightheadedness, shortness of 
breath, and unsteady gait in the setting of increased 
sleepiness, and chronic cough over the preceding 6 months to ___ 
year and increased lower extremity edema over the last 1 month. 
Patient was awaiting CPAP machine in the mail and was currently 
undergoing vascular assessment for suspected venous 
insufficiency as an outpatient. Patient presented by ambulance 
from his home. Symptoms improved with oxygen in the ambulance. 
In the Emergency department, patient was hypertensive to 200/100 
and saturating 97% on 4 liters by nasal cannula. He was 
transferred to the medical floor in stable condition.

#COPD: Chronic cough and subjective shortness of breath 
secondary to undiagnosed and untreated COPD without past 
spirometry. In the ED, the patient received methylprednisolone, 
prednisone 20mg, albuterol, ipratropium, and azithromycin. His 
chest X-ray, physical exam, and labs (Hematocrit 53.2, HCO3- 33) 
were classic for COPD. Given his chronically stable cough 
without change in sputum production, bronchospasm, or evidence 
of infection it was felt that he was not having a COPD 
exacerbation, but rather untreated COPD was contributing to his 
complaints of daytime sleepiness and shortness of breath. 
Patient was given albuterol and ipatropium nebulizers during his 
hospitalization and his oxygenation and subjective feeling of 
shortness of breath improved. He was discharged with 
prescriptions for albuterol and ipatropium, received inhaler 
education, and scheduled for an outpatient pulmonology 
appointment. He expressed a desire to quit smoking and was 
prescribed a nicotine patch and education on quitting. He was 
provided with close follow-up with his primary care physician.

#Obstructive Sleep Apnea(OSA): Patient with multiple risk 
factors for OSA who stated he was suppose to be receiving a CPAP 
machine in the mail and was to be fitted. History of daytime 
sleepiness, fatigue, night time awakenings, and snoring was 
consistent with obstructive sleep apnea. He was provided with a 
CPAP machine overnight and slept well with subsequent 
improvement in symptoms. Likely OSA played a large part in his 
symptoms including his suspected pulmonary hypertension, heart 
failure, and lower extremity edema. He will benefit from CPAP at 
home, which he stated was to be arriving soon. He was scheduled 
for outpatient pulmonology and primary care appointments to 
further assess his disease.   

#Diastolic Congestive Heart Failure: Left sided diastolic 
congestive heart failure in the setting of hypertension likely 
contributing to dyspnea and lower extremity edema. An EKG was 
performed which showed evidence of prior anteroseptal myocardial 
infarction and suggestion of acute inferolateral ischemia. 
Cardiac enzymes were trended and remained negative times 3 with 
a BNP of 304. He was monitored on telemetry throughout his 
hospitalization without any events. A transthoracic echo was 
performed showing a LVEF >75% and left atrial enlargement, 
consistent with diastolic dysfunction. A chest X-Ray showed 
pulmonary edema which was also consistent with congestive heart 
failure and worsening shortness of breath. His lisinopril was 
upped from 20mg to 40 mg daily and his atenolol was decreased to 
25mg. He was provide with close cardiology follow-up at 
discharge.    

#Smoking cessation: ___ pack year history, was smoking 
approximately 1 pack of cigarettes a day. Patient stated he had 
been trying to quit and was previously successful for greater 
than ___ years. He stated his primary care physician was suppose 
to be mailing him a medication to assist him with smoking 
cessation, but he has not received it in the mail. He requested 
and received a nicotine patch in the hospital as well as further 
education on smoking cessation. He was asked to follow-up with 
his primary care physician regarding continued use of the patch 
and slow down titration. 

Patient remained stable throughout the course of his 
hospitalization. He was discharged home with close follow-up 
with his primary care physician, ___, and pulmonology. 
All other chronic conditions were managed without complications. 
He remained full code throughout his admission.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___. 

You were admitted for lightheadedness, shortness of breath, and 
increasing fatigue.  Chest X-ray and blood labs were consistent 
with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) which partly 
explains your chronic cough, shortness of breath, and fatigue. 
The most important step to improving COPD is to quit smoking and 
to use the inhalers as prescribed. You were given education in 
the hospital on how to use these inhalers. You will be sent home 
with a prescription for nicotine patches to help you quit 
smoking and will need to follow-up with your primary care 
physician. Also, it will be important for you to follow-up with 
the pulmonologist to get the appropriate lung test and optimize 
your medication regimen for your COPD.

We also feel obstructive sleep apnea is contributing to your 
frequent night time awakenings, daytime sleepiness, high blood 
pressure, and shortness of breath. You were started on a CPAP 
machine during the night of your hospitalization with 
improvement in your sleep and daytime symptoms. Please make sure 
to get fit for your CPAP and use it while sleeping to improve 
your breathing. 

We were also concerned with your heart given your lower leg 
swelling and high blood pressure. An EKG was performed which did 
now show evidence of an acute heart attack. However, you have 
likely suffered a small heart attack in the past based on the 
EKG findings. The ultrasound of your heart is consistent with 
congestive heart failure. Congestive heart failure can cause 
symptoms of shortness of breath, cough, and swelling in the 
legs. It will be important for you to follow up with a 
cardiologist to further evaluate your heart disease. Your 
Lisinopril was increased to 40mg once daily. Your atenolol was 
decreased to 25mg once a day. Please take these medications as 
prescribed. 

We also discussed our concern over your alcohol consumption and 
potential implications on your liver and other organs. We 
advised you decreased your alcohol consumption to less than 14 
drinks per week and less than ___ drinks per day. 

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.

Impression: A single periampullary diverticulum was found at the 
major papilla.

sphincterotome

the CBD measuring 15 mm.  There were several round filling 
defects compatible with multipl stones in the bile duct at the 
biliary tree.

Then, a sphincteroplasty was performed using a CRE balloon from 
12 mm to 15 mm

were extracted successfully using a balloon. 
Filling defects showed no filling defects. 
Excellent flow of bile was noted. 
 
Recommendations: Return to floor under ongoing care. 
NPO overnight with aggressive IV hydration with LR at 200 cc/hr.

and then advance as tolerated.

fever, jaundice, gastrointestinal bleeding please call ERCP 
fellow on call (___)

Patient is an ___ year old male with a history of CAD s/p 7

before undergoing ERCP with sphincterotomy and sphincteroplasty.

#Choledocholithiasis and pancreatitis- CT abd-pelvis at OSH 
showed mild fat stranding around the head of the pancreas, 
enlarged common bile duct (1.7cm) and several hyperdense stones. 
His ALT and AST were elevated. His ALP, lipase, amylase, total 
bilirubin and direct bilirubin were also elevated. On day 1 of 
his hospital stay at ___, acute cornary syndrome was ruled out 
as below. On day 2, ERCP was performed. A sphincterotomy 
followed by a sphincteroplasty was performed and five large 
round yellowish stones and large amount of sludge were 
extracted. Patient returned to floor for continued care. He was 
kept NPO overnight with IV hydration and his diet was advanced 
as tolerated and the following day he tolerated PO and was 
discharged home.  ERCP team felt that this resolved and patient 
would only need to f.u with PCP rather than ERCP team. His abd 
pain improved as well and he was d/c'd with no abdominal pain, 
eating and drinking well.

#r/o acute coronary syndrome- At ___ Troponin I 
was elevated at 0.876. EKG per report showed paced ryhthm. At 
the ___ ED, troponin T was 0.11, CK 649 and MB 11. ECG showed 
sinus, rate 79, intermittent paced rhythm, no clear ischemic 
changes. Of note Cr was elev 1.9 when he was admitted to ___ 
so it is possible that elevated Cr may have contributed to the 
elev trop. He was given 1L NS. On the floor he was also given 
aspirin 325, atorvastatin 80 and metoprolol tartrate 12.5 mg. 
Patient denied any epigastric pain throughout his entire 
hospital course. His cardiac biomarkers were rechecked and were 
downtrending. Patient had an echo with an unchanged EF and no 
new wall motion abnormalities. Given normal echo and 
downtrending biomarkers, patient was cleared for ERCP.  Initial 
elevation of cardiac enzymes was thought to be secondary to 
prerenal failure (Cr 1.9 at its highest) in the setting of 
vomiting and decreased PO intake. Demand ischemia in the setting 
of pancreatitis and choledocholithiasis is also possible as 
well. He had no chest pain on day of d/c and was advised to f/u 
with his cardiologist for a stress test pMIBI as an outpatient.

# Narrow complex tachycardia
Presented with episode of palpitations, persistent for about 20
minutes, more severe than two prior episodes over the past six
months. No associated symptoms. Rhythm strip from EMS per 
cardiology fellow demonstrated NCT with short RP retrograde P 
waves, consistent with likely AVNRT vs. AVRT. Repeat EKG without 
evidence of bypass track, making AVNRT more likely. Likely 
triggered in setting of diarrheal illness. Troponins x2 
negative. Long discussion had with patient; given asymptomatic 
and no red flag signs/angina at baseline, it was felt safe to 
discharge him with close follow-up. Recommend monitoring with 
ZioPatch to elucidate further the etiology of these episodes. If 
frequency increases, recommend up-titration of beta blocker vs. 
transition to calcium blocker, although patient reluctant to do 
same this admission.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills.

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy. 

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon or your primary physician.

6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in two (2) weeks.

7. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).

8. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated.  No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. Ambulate 5 times 
per day

Initial ECG - Normal sinus rhythm. A-V conduction delay. Delayed 
R wave transition. T wave inversions in leads V5-V6 and in leads 
I and aVL suggestive of anterolateral myocardial ischemia. 
Compared to the previous tracing of ___ the anterolateral ST 
segment abnormalities are more prominent. Clinical correlation 
is suggested.

Cardiac Cath - COMMENTS:     
1. Selective coronary angiography in this right dominant system 
demonstrated three vessel coronary disease. The LMCA had no 
significant stenoses. The LAD had a 100% stenosis in the 
mid-portion. The ramus had an 80% stenosis at the origin. The Cx 
had a 30% stenosis at the origin, an 80% stenosis at the 
mid-portion and an 80% distal stenosis.
2. Arterial conduit angiography revealed a patent LIMA and 
patent radial artery graft to D1.
3. Successful PTCA and stenting of the mid RCA with a 2.5 x 28mm 
Promus drug eluting stent which was postdilated to 2.75mm.
4. Successful direct stenting of the ostial RCA with a 2.5 x 
15mm Promus drug eluting stent which was postdilated to 2.75mm. 
Final angiography revealed no residual stenosis, no 
angiographically apparent dissection, and TIMI 3 flow. (see PTCA 
comments for details) 
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:    
1. Three vessel coronary artery disease.
2. Patent LIMA-LAD and radial artery-diagonal grafts.
3. Successful PTCA and stenting of the mid RCA.
4. Successful direct stenting of the ostial RCA.

CXR - FINDINGS: In comparison with the study of ___, there 
is again evidence of previous CABG with intact midline sternal 
wires. Cardiomegaly persists, though there is no vascular 
congestion, pleural effusion, or acute focal pneumonia.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o M with PMHx of CAD (s/p stent to LAD in ___ and CABGx2 
in ___, carotid stenosis (s/p stenting in ___, DM, HTN, HL 
presents after having an abnormal stress 2 days ago for pre-cath 
hydration and cardiac catheterization tomorrow.

# Coronary Artery Disease - On arrival to the floor, the patient 
denied any recent chest pain.   The patient received 
pre-catheterization hydration per protocol with normal saline 
and bicarbonate.  He also received mucomyst.  He was continued 
on his aspirin, plavix, metoprolol, and simvastatin.  On the 
morning following his admission, the patient underwent cardiac 
catheterization.  He had 2 drug eluting stents placed in his RCA 
(see above for further details).  His post-catheterization 
course was slightly complicated by hypertension, initially 
requiring a nitroglycerine drip.  His blood pressure decreased 
somewhat but still remained above goal.  At discharge, his 
amlodipine was uptitrated in an attempt to get better control of 
his blood pressure.

# Chronic Diastolic Heart Failure - The patient has a history of 
heart failure, with recent echo showing diastolic dysfunction 
with EF of 70%.  The patient did have significant ___ edema on 
exam; however, his lungs were clear.  His lasix were held during 
his pre-catheterization hydration.  After his catheterization 
procedure, he continued to receive hydration.  His creatinine 
was monitored.  After his hydration was complete, he was 
restarted on his home lasix regimen.

# DM - The patient was continued on his home regimen of Lantus 
and Humalog.  He was also continued on his home dose of 
amitriptyline for diabetic neuropathy.

# HTN - The patient was noted to be hypertensive on arrival to 
the floor.  He was continued on his home regimen of norvasc and 
metoprolol tartrate.  After catheterization, he did have some 
hypertension that initally required a nitroglycerine drip and 
later required a one-time dose of PO labetalol.  At discharge, 
the patient's blood pressures were still not at goal.  His 
amlodipine was uptitrated in an attempt to better control his 
blood pressure.

# Questionable Red Stools - On H&P, the patient reported a 
recent history of loose, red stools.  He did not have any stools 
while hospitalized to guaiac.  His hematocrit was monitored and 
was noted to decrease with hydration but to remain basically 
stable after that (36.1 -> 31.2 -> 29.2).  Iron studies were 
consistent with iron deficieny.  The reticulocyte count was not 
elevated.  Further work-up of this problem should be done as an 
outpatient.

# Hyperlipidemia - The patient was continued on his home regimen 
of simvastatin, zetia, and niacin.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. M with dementia, CAD, CHF (unknonw EF), HTN, and history 
of falls, who presents s/p fall at nursing home with 
hypoglycemia.  

# Hypoglycemia. Patient noted to be severely hypoglycemic on 
labs in ED with finger stick of 29.  The etiology of 
hypoglycemia was thought to be secondary to malnutrition, 
especially with elevated INR of 1.5 in absence of other liver 
abnormalities.  As per nursing home, the patient has no history 
of diabetes and received no hypoglycemic medication in error.  
Infectious evaluation with urinalysis, chest x-ray was also 
negative.  Renal function was normal.  Insulin and c-peptide 
levels were low making a diagnosis of an insulinoma very 
unlikely. Prior to surgical fixation of left femur fracture, 
patient was NPO and maintained on a D51/2 NS drip.  Following 
ORIF, this was discontinued with the presumption that recurrent 
hypoglycemia could be avoided with adequate oral intake.  Blood 
glucose levels were checked every 4 hours and on ___ patient 
was noted to have ___ of 48, hypotension with SBP in ___, and 
periods of apnea.  Given 1 amp D50, fluid bolus of 750cc NS and 
1 UpRBC for ___ blood loss with normalization of 
vital signs and mental status returning to baseline.  Due to 
recurrent hypoglycemia, patient was maintained on glucose drip.  
Patient was noted to have dysphagia with poor oral intake and a 
speech/ swallow consultation recommended pureed diet with 
nectar-thickened liquids.  Despite dietary modification and 
nursing staff prompting, patient's oral intake did not improve 
and malnurishment was felt to be due to perioperative delerium 
with underlying advanced dementia.  The patient's daughter, his 
health care proxy, did not wish to pursue a PEG tube or other 
invasive methods to prolong life.  However, she agreed to 
temporizing methods to support patient through post-operative 
period to see if he would regain his desire to take in PO.  The 
patient was maintained on a D10 drip and, over the course of his 
hospitalization, he continued to have poor oral intake related 
to his advanced dementia. He was evaluated by the endocrinology 
service; given his low insulin levels and high 
beta-hydroxybutyrate level, it was felt that his persistent 
hypoglycemia was related to malnutrition and poor oral intake. 
After a lengthy meeting with the patient's daughter, it was 
decided, given the low likelihood that the patient would be able 
to progress back to the functional state he had been in the past 
and the fact that he was unable to support his own nutrition 
through PO intake, that the patient would be transitioned to 
comfort measures only. The D10 drip was stopped and 
non-essential medications were stopped. The patient passed away 
comfortably on ___.

# Hypoxia: Pt developed worsening hypoxia on ___. CXR showed 
new infiltrate. There was concern for aspiration, and the 
patient was started on cipro/flagyl. Additionally, the patient 
was grossly fluid overloaded from his continuous D10 drip. Of 
note, the patient did not spike any fevers nor did he develop a 
leukocytosis. Antibiotics were continued until the patient was 
made CMO. The patient was given lasix boluses in attempts to 
remove some fluid; however, his urine output did not respond 
very well.

# Left comminuted intertrochanteric femur fracture: Presented 
with left femur fracture after fall.  On ___, patient 
underwent uncomplicated ORIF of fracture.  Post-operatively, he 
was placed on enoxaparin to reduce risk of DVT formation.  For 
periprocedural blood loss, he was transfused 1 UpRBC and 
hematocrit stabilized at ___.   Initially pain was managed 
with acetaminophen around the clock and morphine as needed for 
breakthrough.  On ___, patient had a hypoglycemic episode with 
periods of observed apnea (see below), and as morphine may have 
been contributing to respiratory depression, it  was 
discontinued.  Breakthrough pain was managed with  oxycodone 
2.5mg as needed with good results.  He was maintained on vitamin 
D/ calcium through duration of hospital stay for underlying 
osteopenia/ osteoporosis.  Patient remained non-weight- bearing 
throughout hospital stay as per orthopedic recommendation.

# s/p Fall: As above, patient presented after an unwitnessed 
fall most likely mechanical +/- hypoglycemia.  ACS was ruled out 
with serially EKGs and flat cardiac enzymes x 3.  Patient was 
monitored on telemetry with no evidence of arrhythmia.  CT head 
showed no evidence of acute intracranial pathology that could 
have caused syncope.  As above, the fall resulted in a left 
femur fracture, managed by surgical fixation.   CT C-spine 
showed severe multilevel DJD with large posterior osteophytes 
and C3-4 predisposing to cord injury in the setting of trauma. 
Initially patient was placed in a ___ until C-spine was 
cleared by ortho.  No evidence of other mechanical injury 
resulting from fall.

#  CHF with unknown EF:  Volume status was monitored carefully 
throughout hospitalization especially in the setting of unknown 
ejection fraction, poor PO intake and continuous fluid 
requirements due to hypoglycemia.  Upon hospitalization, patient 
appeared hypovolemic and his furosemide was held pending 
surgery.   Through hospital course, patient became volume 
overloaded with pleural effusions on CXR and pitting edema in 
lower extremities.  Third spacing due to low oncotic pressure 
(albumin of 2.8) likely contributed.  Fluid overload managed 
with boluses of lasix 10mg IV prn to keep respiratory status 
stabilized.  Lisinopril and metoprolol were held in setting of 
low blood pressure. As above, the patient was given lasix in 
attempts to remove fluid; however, his urine output became less 
and less responsive. Ultimately, the patient was made CMO and 
passed away.

# Normocytic anemia: admitted with Hct around 35. Required 1U 
pRBC following surgery.  Hct was trended through hospitalization 
and remained stable.

#  Psych: Initially continued sertraline, risperidone, depakote 
for unknown mood d/o. Sertraline was ultimately d/c'ed out of 
concern that it could contribute to hypoglycemia; however, 
hypoglycemia did not improve after sertraline was stopped.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F with PMH of nonischemic cardiomyopathy 
(EF 25% on ___, HTN, mitral valve prolapse, intermittent 
LBBB, and atrial fibrillation who was admitted for progressively 
worsening SOB for the over 3 days secondary to CHF exacerbation. 

. 
# Cardiac arrest: on ___, patient was successfully cardioverted 
to normal sinus rhythem. She was given a dose of dofetilide. 
Later that day it was noted that her QTc was elongated from 
previously. That evening, she had a cardiac arrest secondary to 
torsades de pointes and ventricular fibrillation. She was 
defibrillated after 60 seconds and had ROSC and regained 
consciousness. She was briefly transferred to the CCU, where her 
magnesium and potassium were repleted and serial EKGs showed 
decreasing QTc interval. 

# Acute on chronic CHF:  Patient reported history of dyspnea on 
exertion, orthopnea, PND and new onset ankle swelling.  Has 
known history of CHF with EF 25% in ___. After receiving 
Lasix 40mg IV in the ER, she put out 800cc and dyspnea resolved. 
 Initial history and exam consistent with a CHF exacerbation.  
___ have baseline worsening EF as she has had such symptoms for 
approximately 2 weeks which improved with Lasix.  ___ be 
secondary to worsening EF in combination with afib with RVR.  
Patient's beta blocker was changed on ___ but she has been 
self titrating the medication and not receiving enough beta 
blockade.  (Was on Metoprolol XL 100, this was d/c'ed on 
___ and started on Carvedilol 6.25 mg bid.  Instead, taking 
Metoprolol 50 daily and Carvedilol 3.125 daily.) Therefore, her 
rate was not well controlled which is likely stressing the heart 
by decreasing adequate forward flow.  Initially, changed to 
carvedilol for rate control.  On ___, carvedilol switched to 
metoprolol and rate better controlled. Her metoprolol dose was 
adjusted again secondary to her Afib and changed up to metop 
150XL. .Patient was optimized on an oral regimen of Lasix prior 
to discharge and remained euvolemic. Patient to receive 20meqK 
replacement on discharge as well to supplement lasix.
.
# Paroxysmal A-fib/RHYTHM: Patient with known history of atrial 
fibrillation.  Rate not well controlled on Carvedilol and 
digoxin.  Patient was instead started on metoprolol with much 
better rate control.  Just started on Coumadin 5mg qd 5 days 
prior to admission. Patient continued anticoagulation with 
coumadin throughout stay (dosage adjustments made per INR). ___ 
had TEE with cardiovesion ___, initiall successful then patient 
developed torsades in the afternoon which responded to 
magnesium. Shortly thereafter patient coded with Vfib, with CPR 
performed for 1 minute, received one shock and had ROSC. Pt had 
continuous Mg replacement. Pt was then brought back to the floor 
in stable condition. She continued to be in Afib and had an 
increase in her metoprolol dose for rate control. Patient was 
then started  Amio gtt and load. She had inital attempt at BIV 
ICD placement for LBBB on ___ which was unsuccessful. The 
following day patient had repeat procedure and successful BIV 
ICD placement. Patient remained in Afib s/p procedure, and 
continued her anticoagulation, and will continue PO amio and 
metoprolol for control. Warfarin dose decreased from 6 to 5 
prior to discharge due to supratherapuetic INR 3.1. She is to 
follow up with Dr. ___ the next 2 weeks, and device 
clinic on ___ for evaluation of pacemaker. Pt also will 
complete 6 day course of Keflex for pacemaker placement. 

  
# CORONARIES: No history of CAD.  LDL was 147 in ___.  She is 
not on a statin because she has function limiting myalgias as a 
side effect. Pt started on ASA 81 during hospitilazation and to 
continue as outpatient. 
.
.  
# Hyponatremia: Patient was hyponatremic at 129 on admission, Na 
was lowest at 126.  Baseline in last several years (several data 
points) has been in the mid to low 130s. Patient was 
asymptomatic, mentating well.  ___ have been secondary to 
combination of diuretics as well as CHF exacerbation leading to 
intravascular depletion and ADH secretion.  Na improved with 1.5

returned back to her baseline upon discharge, she is to follow

# Rash: Patient with new macular rash as of morning of admission 
on lower abdomen, lower back and breasts.  Denied any new

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o man with PMHx of HTN, HLD, and no known CAD that 
presented with several week h/o of worsening DOE. Initially 
thought to represent ___ exacerbation, as he was volume 
overloaded and had SBP in 170's with preserved EF on initial 
TTE. Diuresed to dry weight with resolution of symptoms. 
Underwent further screening tests, including stress MIBI and 
repeat TTE. Reevaluation of heart function with MIBI 
demonstrated depressed EF (30%). Eventually underwent r. and l. 
heart catheterization which demonstrated single vessel CAD and 
severe AS. Evaluated by cardiac surg for aortic valve 
replacement vs. repair and potential SVG to RCA. Rather than 
stay in-house prior to surgery, he opted to go home and discuss 
options with family.     
.
#Severe AS: He presented with worsening DOE that was initially 
thought related to ___ rather than underlying valvular disease, 
as his EF was preserved on intitial TTE. Same study documented 
only moderate AS. Eventually underwent r. and l. heart 
catheterization which demonstrated an ___ of 0.77cm. As pt has 
symptoms of heart failure and reduced EF (see below), he is a 
candidate for AVR. Of note, no history of angina or syncope. Pt 
was amenable to valve replacement, but did not wish to have 
work-up done as inpatient. He prefers to go home and talk over 
with his family. Started on CHF meds (see below). Avoided 
overdiuresis given his pre-load dependence.
.
#Acute sCHF exacerbation: Pt came in with worsening DOE and 
lower extremity swelling. He had difficulty making it from 
clinic to the hospital ___ symptoms. CTA was performed to rule 
out PE. No PE was noted. He was diuresed with IV lasix, and DOE 
resolved. It is unclear whether initial presentation was ___ 
___ vs ___ as initial echo documented low normal LVEF and mild 
LVH. The images were noted to be suboptimal. Had stress MIBI 
with calulated EF of 30%. Despite discordant echo results 
showing preserved EF, it appeared that depressed EF (~30%) on 
stress MIBI was more compatible with clinical picture. Started 
on ___ (cough with ACE-I), toprol xL and maintenance diuretic 
prior to discharge.
.
#CAD: No known cardiac disease prior to admission. Pt with total 
occlusion of proximal RCA with good collateral flow. Likely a 
candidate for bypass surgery. No h/o angina or anginal 
equivalent. Started on atorvastatin and toprol xL. 
.
# Elevated ESR/CRP: Initial ESR/CRP elevated. Thought to be ___ 
recent upper respiratory infection.  
.
# Elevated Lactate: Resolved on admission. No localizing s/sx 
other than cough and SOB. Possibly related to mild hypoxia with

.
# Fever/Leukocytosis: Initially presented with low grade fever 
and leukocytosis, which resolved during admission. Likely 
related to viral URI. Blood and urine cx negative
.

___ y/o M with PMHx of GSW to the chest resulting in multiple 
thoracic and abdominal injuries including tricuspid valve damage 
s/p TVR, RV free wall and septum perforation s/p repair. 
Presented with new onset R sided heart failure. Initially 
thought to be secondary to small TV replacement, however, after 
large volume diuresis, HD parameters normalized and TV gradient 
<4mm hg. Discharged home with PO lasix and instructed to engage 
in low salt diet.
.

# Acute decompensated CHF: Pt presented with clinical e/o both R 
and L sided CHF including 3+ BLE to knees, JVD, and crackles. 
Given recent TVR, thought that he may have an undersized valve 
along with decreased RV systolic function ___ GSW. LVEF was 
normal on initial echo, but TTE with mild/moderate MR, which may 
be contributing to his pulmonary edema. Placed on fluid and Na 
restriction, with daily weights and I/Os. Started on lasix gtt 
at 10cc/hr, and diuresed until edema resolved. This resulted in 
resolution of all symptoms. All electrolytes were agressively 
repleted. Pt underwent cardiac catheterization which showed no 
CAD, step-up or step-downs in O2, and normal filling pressures. 
Echo after diuresis did not demonstrate significant gradient 
across tricuspid valve replacement, so patient was discharged 
home on PO diuretics and instructed to keep to low soduium diet. 
Unclear of exact etiology of exacerbation. 
.

likely secondary to congestive hepatopathy, as it resolved with 
diuresis. RUQ U/S showed findings concerning for cirrhsis, which 
will likely need to be followed up as outpatient. Transaminases 
WNL.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with abdominal pain. This was due to a 
blockage in your bile duct. The GI team attempted ERCP but were 
unable to complete. You underwent interventional radiology 
procedure with removal of stone, and placement of drains (both 
internal and external drains). These were working well and your 
tests improved. You will have 4 more days of antibiotics 
(cirpofloxacin and flagyl). In addition, you will need to follow 
up with interventional radiology for further management of your 
drains. The interventional radiology team will contact you to 
arrange for follow up. Finally, you need to have your 
gallbladder removed. This can be done near your home. Please 
arrange this with your PCP. 

Of note, if you develop worsening pain, fevers, confusion or 
other worrisome symptoms please present to an emergency 
department. If you develop these symptoms you should uncap your 
external drain and connect to a bag.

You were prescribed oxycodone for pain. This pain shoudl improve 
over the next couple of weeks. You were discharged with 
oxycodone. If your pain is worsening or not resolving please 
discuss with PCP or present to ED. Of note, this medication will 
make you tired. Do not drive or drink alcohol while on this 
medication.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to Urology after undergoing 
laparoscopic LEFT partial nephrectomy. No concerning 
intra-operative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details.  The patient received perioperative antibiotic 
prophylaxis. 

FICU COURSE:
Post Urologic surgery patient transferred to FICU d/t 
hypotension and requirement for pressors. Patient was on Neo, 
which was quickly weaned in <24 hours. Etiology likely d/t 
significant sensitivity to opioids and anesthesia (as documented 
on prior admissions). We avoided all opioids for remainder of 
her stay, instead used Tramadol and Toradol for pain control.  
Subsequently, while in the ___ patient developed worsening 
hypoxemic, hypercarbic respiratory distress. She has a long COPD 
history with long smoking history. Initialy CXR's suggested both 
volume overload and RUL + LLL infiltrates so patient was started 
on HCAP coverage and aggressive diuresis. Patient was maintained 
net negative daily, at least 1L with prn IV Lasix. CXR and 
respiratory status continued to worsen and ARDS was suspected so 
pt was eventually intubated. Pt was further diuresed during 
intubation, then extubated in about 18 hours. Post extubation 
patient's respiratory status was tenuous so a CT Chest was 
checked that should significant b/l Pleural Effusions. She had a 
right sided thoracentesis with significant improvement in her 
respiratory status. Fluid was transudative, most likely from 
___ exacerbation in a COPD patient, likely causing perfusion to 
poorly ventilated zones. She was further diuresed and prior to 
floor transfer she was on 3L NC with SaO2 93-95% and 
comfortable. 

POST FICU:  Ms. ___ transferred to the general surgical 
floor on POD8 where she remained without incident until 
discharge on POD10.  An ultrasound was obtained to rule out 
right upper extremity thrombosis (given some increased right arm 
edema), antibiotics were discontinued and her foley removed.  
The remainder of the hospital course was relatively 
unremarkable. The patient was discharged in stable condition, 
eating well, ambulating independently, voiding without 
difficulty, and with pain control on oral analgesics. On exam, 
incision was clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of 
hematoma collection or infection. The patient was given explicit 
instructions to follow-up in clinic in approximately four weeks 
time for ___ evaluation with Dr. ___ 
back to her PCP for routine ___ evaluation and set-up 
with pulmonary for ongoing work-up of her CPOD and requirement 
of supplemental oxygen. She was discharged home with visiting 
nurse services, home oxygen services and home physical therapy.

Discharge Instructions:
-Please also refer to the provided written instructions on 
___ care, instructions and expectations made 
available from Dr. ___ office.

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications except as noted. 
ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes 
and your ___ course with your primary care doctor.

-___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision 
sites; remember to log roll onto your side and then use your 
hands to push yourself upright while taking advantage of the 
momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground.

--There may be bandage strips called steristrips which have 
been applied to reinforce wound closure.  Allow these bandage 
strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY 
REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may 
get the steristrips wet.

-Please AVOID aspirin or aspirin containing products and 
supplements that may have blood-thinning effects (like Fish 
Oil, Vitamin E, etc.) unless you have otherwise been advised.

-IBUPROFEN (the ingredient of Advil, Motrin, etc.) may be taken 
even though you may also be taking Tylenol/Acetaminophen. You 
may alternate these medications for pain control.  For pain 
control, try TYLENOL FIRST, then ibuprofen, and then take the 
narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional pain relief 
is needed.

-Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. Please discontinue 
taking and notify your doctor should you develop blood in your 
stool (dark, tarry stools)

-Call your Urologist's office to schedule/confirm your follow-up 
appointment in 4 weeks AND if you have any questions.

-Please call your primary care physician, ___, 
pulmonology clinic for a follow up appointment. 

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely 
walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a 
couch potato

-Tylenol should be your first-line pain medication. A narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___. 
REPLACE the Tylenol with this narcotic pain medication if 
additional pain control is needed.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up 

-You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or 
bathe

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool-softener, NOT a laxative

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.

- You will be sent home on home supplemental oxygen.

valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve 
prolapse. No mass or vegetation is seen on the mitral valve. 
Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve 
leaflets are mildly thickened. There is moderate pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. 
.
IMPRESSION: No endocarditis or abscess seen (trans-thoracic echo 
cannot exclude). Mild focal LV systolic dysfunction consistent 
with CAD (inferior ischemia/infarction). Mild aortic 
regurgitation.
.
CXR:  No previous images. Low lung volumes may account for the 
prominence of the transverse diameter of the heart. No evidence 
of vascular congestion, pleural effusion, or acute pneumonia. 
.

wedge-shaped 
geographic hypodense lesion at the lower pole, most likely acute 
or subacute infarct. Alternatively, this could represent 
abscess, although does not demonstrate rim enhancement. 
.

artery, with possible arterial filling defect. However, no other 
end organ infarct is evident in the torso. 
.

.

.

colectomy, with stranding, but no focal collection to indicate 
abscess.

6. Moderate ascites tracking through the abdomen and pelvis. No 
focal 
collection.

assessed on single-phase contrast study.

pancreatic edema.  Given dilated bile ducts, history of 
cholelithiasis, and previous manipulation of the bile ducts 
initially major concern was for an obstructing stone.  Multiple 
imaging studies (including OSH CT, OSH U/S, and MRCP at ___ 
all showed no obstructing stone of flow void.  Therefore, GI and 
surgery both felt that dilation was chronic after surgery and 
pancreatitis was unrelated.   Therefore, patient was managed 
conservatively with fluids, analgesia, and NPO status.  On 
hospital day three he began to notice significant improvement in 
is pain and was transitioned to an oral diet and oral analgesia. 
 He handled advancement of his diet well.  Regarding etiology of 
pancreatitis this remains unknown.  Given no stone and patient 
emphatically denied heavy alcohol use presumably due to 
medication or idiopathic.  Highest probability med among those 
he takes is simvastatin so this was held and will continue to be 
held at discharge (though still considered unlikely culprit as 
he had been on it for some time).  He should discuss with his 
PCP attempting another statin as this continues to be a quite 
unlikely cause.  Metformin was also held in the hospital and on 
discharge as the starting and stopping of this med prior to 
presentation makes it the only major change in his meds.  It is 
not a typical culprit medication for pancreatitis but as he also 
had GI symptoms he found extremely unpleasant with it he had it 
held and will discuss alternative agents of glycemic control 
with his PCP.   

2) Hyperbilirubinemia- The patient presented with a normal 
bilirubin but then this increased to a peak of 2.8.  This was 
primarily an indirect hyperbilirubinemia and etiology was 
unclear.  There were no other signs or symptoms to suggest 
hemolysis and after a brief increase this sharply improved so it 
was 2.0 on day of discharge.  Pt will follow up with his PCP for 
___ recheck.  

3) Hypotension: Pt had transient hypotension prior to 
hospitalization at home. Unclear etiology.  He was initially 
treated with ampicillin-sublactam for presumed cholangitis but 
given not a great story for obstruction and no right upper 
quadrant pain this was stopped on hospital day 2.  He was never 
hypotensive again and cultures remained negative.  Suspicion 
this was perhaps due to a vagal episode in context of new pain, 
chills, and nausea.  During hospitalization the patient had one 
low grade fever to 100.7 but given negative infectious work up 
this was thought due to pancreatitis.  At time of discharge he 
had been off antibiotics for >48 hours with steady improvement 
in his clinical picture.

4) Acute on chronic diastolic CHF/mild hypoxia- Mr ___ had 
signs of diastolic dysfunction on echo during his last 
hospitalization and during this hospitalization in the context 
of getting large volumes of fluid and having not a great deal of 
outs he had hypoxia to high ___ on room air and crackles on lung 
exam (was never really dypsneic).  Imaging consistent with 
volume overload.  As he was still NPO and was making good urine 
he was allowed to autodiurese.  At time of discharge, pt was 
sating 96% on RA and maintained sats >90% during ambulation. Pt 
should follow up in the outpatient setting can can consider PFTs 
and pulmonology consult. Pt likely has an element of COPD due to 
long smoking history. However, he did not display signs of flare 
during admission.

5) Pneumobilia: Pt had pneumobilia on initial imaging that was 
discussed with surgery who felt it was post procedural air and 
did not suggest abdominal catastrophe (exam was consistent with 
this as well) and further imaging revealed no evolution or 
change.  

6) Anxiety: he was continued on his home alprazolam PRN

7) Diabetes Mellitus type 2, uncontrolled, without complication: 
He was transitioned to insulin sliding scale on presentation and 
will be transitioned back to PO anti-hypoglycemics at discharge. 
 Metformin held ("see discussion under Acute Pancreatitis")

8) Hypertension: His ACEi was initially held due to reported 
hypotension at home.  His renal function remained stable and he 
had no further hypotension so this was restarted.
.
Transitional Issues:
-He will follow up with his PCP to monitor bilirubin and to make 
sure this resolved to the normal range
-He will follow up with his PCP to discuss restarting another 
statin given unclear simvastatin was cause of pancreatitis
-He will follow up with his PCP to discuss diabetes management 
as Mr ___ reports a pretty classical pattern of GI 
disturbance due to metformin and is quite reluctant to take this 
going forward, this will be held on discharge and he will follow

ACUTE ISSUES:
==============
# Acute Mixed Hypoxemic/Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure
# Probable mild smoke inhalation injury 
Patient was pulled unconscious from a fire in his home. He was 
initially requiring nonrebreather, wheezing, on ___ NC in the 
ED and initial blood gases were concerning for both hypoxemic 
and hypercarbic respiratory failure. His prior blood gasses 
suggested against chronic hypercarbia. Initially, was planned 
for ICU admission. In ED, after he received IV steroids and 
nebulizer x1, improved both in terms of his acid/base status and 
his encephalopathy. Therefore, admitted to the general medicine 
floor, and was breathing comfortably on RA. ED had lower concern 
for smoke inhalation injury. Attempted to institute nebulizer 
treatments during admission, but patient declined.

# Encephalopathy 
Initially confused and altered in ED, then returned back to 
baseline but remained tangential in his speech and somewhat 
inattentive. Suspect related to inhalation rather than hepatic 
encephalopathy, though he is on chronic opioids and unclear if 
he may have overdosed. Did not require narcan in ED. Tox screen 
negative for all except opiates and methadone. He had no 
asterixis to suggestive hepatic encephalopathy.

# Abdominal Pain and Distension
# Ascites 
# Secondary bacterial peritonitis
Reported abdominal pain and distension, initially suspected from 
ascites as he seemed overall fluid overloaded despite reporting 
compliance with diuretics (had lower extremity edema to the 
buttocks as well). Has a history of chronic PVT and SVT. Does 
not follow low salt diet or fluid restriction at home. RUQUS 
showed large volume ascites. Paracentesis was done in ED, 
initially negative, but subsequent paracentesis with culture 
growing E. coli and strep salivarius (likely contaminant), 
thought to be potentially secondary bacterial peritonitis from 
bowel microperforation. He clinically appeared well. He 
completed Zosyn for a ___nd was switched to 
cefpodoxime for phrophylaxis at 200mg daily. Diuretics were held 
in the setting of ___, discussed below, and restarted at lower 
dose prior to discharge, as discussed below. Nutrition was 
consulted to emphasize adherence to 2g sodium diet and 2L fluid 
restriction. 

# ___ 
Cr peaked at 1.5 from baseline of 1.0. Improved with albumin 
100g ___, 60g ___. He was also given additional 25 g on ___ 
after paracentesis, and 25g on ___ for mildly low sodium. 
Spironolactone and Lasix were initially held, but restarted at 
50 and 20, respectively. He will continue this at discharge. 
Nadalol was held and should continue to be held at discharge.

# Decompensated HCV cirrhosis
# Esophageal varices s/p banding
He has cirrhosis ___ HCV (genotype 2, s/p Epclusa and ribavirin) 
c/b esophageal varices s/p ligation on Nadolol, recent banding 
___ for 2 cords of grade II varices in distal esophagus, 
portal hypertensive gastropathy, rectal varices, Hx HE on 
Lactulose, portal and splenic vein thromboses ___, chronic 
portal vein thrombosis ___, no longer on transplant list (too 
well). Concern for decompensated cirrhosis based on above 
(ascites, ___ and worsening LFTs. LFTs improved rapidly, 
suggesting that they were a change in setting of smoke 
inhalation/hypoxia. RUQUS with patent portal vessels and no 
acute cause for decompensation. Reported only taking Lactulose 
daily instead of TID as prescribed. For esophageal varices s/p 
ligation, EGD was done and revealed varices s/p banding, no 
further procedure required at this time. Nadalol was held at 
discharge given ___.

# Multiple abdominal venous thrombi
Has had thrombi in multiple areas on prior imaging as well. CT 
from ___ showing increased superior mesenteric vein thrombosis, 
and stable splenic, main portal, and right portal vein thrombi. 
Discussed with hepatology, since these are chronic, risk of
anticoagulation (especially with varcies) exceeds benefit. 
Anticoagulation was deferred.

# Thrombocytopenia, pancytopneia
Acute on chronic thrombocytopenia thought i/s/o decompensated 
cirrhosis, possible consumption from fall and guaiac + stool, 
and also could be worsened in setting of cefpodoxime 
prophylaxis. Patient

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You came the hospital after being pulled out of a fire at your 
home. You likely suffered some smoke inhalation injury to your 
lungs but you recovered quickly.

You also were found to have significant volume overload on exam.

While you were here:
- Your breathing and altered mental status improved.
- You had an infection in your belly that we treated with IV 
antibiotics
- You had some kidney injury that improved with IV albumin
- You had an EGD that showed varices and prior banding, along 
with some evidence of high blood pressures in the stomach.

- see below for medicine and followup appointments
- stick to a low salt diet and do not drink more than 2 liters 
of fluids per day
- weigh yourself every morning and call your doctor if your 
weight changes by more than 3 pounds in one day, or 5 pounds in 
one week.

It was a pleasure caring for you and we wish you the best,
Your ___ Team

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old woman with an extensive past medical 
history presenting with shortness of breath and abdominal pain.  

.  
# Shortness of breath: She has many possible reasons to be short 
of breath. Radiology was concerned for pneumonia. She does not 
have fevers/chills/cough and CT abdomen not concerning for 
pneumonia.  Did not keep patient on antibiotics. Regarding her 
underlying disease:  
1) Moderate restrictive disease with TLC 52% was identified in 
___, and the etiology has not been identified as far as I can 
tell. Her VC with bedside spirometry was stable but low on 
admission; vital capacity 1.6 L and NIF 20 with poor effort  2) 
Severe pulmonary HTN was also diagnosed and confirmed on cath in 
___. However, this was initially thought to be secondary to 
inhaled cocaine use, which she currently denies although Utox 
positive for cocaine. Crack-induced pulmonary hypertension seems 
to be mostly related to local vasocontstrictive effects and thus 
only present in the setting of active use, but there may be some 
degree of chronic granulomatous inflammation triggered by former 
use. She could also have primary pulmonary hypertension. In any 
case, she needs further outpatient evaluation of the status of 
her pulmonary hypertension and treatment if this is indeed the 
cause of her severe shortness of breath.  
3) Other possible causes of her chronic shortness of breath 
include asthma, but no wheezing and currently moving good air. 
Patient kept on home regimen of Flovent with nebs prn wheezing.  
Chronic inflammatory demyelinating mononeuropathy (CIDM) was 
also initially on the differential although, per the ED, this 
was considered unlikely after neurology attending weighed in. 
She doesn't have enough ascites on exam to make this the likely 
cause. L-sided heart failure also on the differential but less 
likely given CXR and exam.  
.
TTE was done to evaluate for evidence of persistent pulmonary 
HTN  and showed severe pulmonary HTN.  Recommend outpatient 
PFTs/pulmonary visit. Per neurology, ordered TSH (normal). 
Neurology consult also recommended outpatient thyroid US, which 
we will defer to PCP.  Continued her home regimen of Flovent, 
nebs prn wheezing (none on discharge), and O2 as needed to 
maintain O2 Sat >92%
.
#Right heart failure: Heart size enlarged on CXR.  CTabdomen 
with evidence of RHF.  BNP elevated at 3401 (has been much 
higher in past).  Patient certainly at risk for right heart 
failure secondary to chronic pulmonary HTN. TTE showed severe 
pulmonary HTN
.  
# abdominal pain: Chronic but worsening over the past few 
months. CT abdomen without any acute process. History not 
consistent with recurrence of ulcer, and patient on both PPI and 
H2 blocker. She doesn't have tense ascites causing this. The 
pain is more diffuse than what would be expected if this were 
related to her liver disease (hepatic fibrosis, stage 2 pr 
biopsy ___ on admission, nl ALT with slightly elevated AST).  
The underlying process has not been identified despite regular 
follow up with GI in ___, but the patient has been failing to 
keep her appointments over the past 6 months. Patient has 
outpatient appointments with GI including an appointment for 
endoscopy within the next month.  Currently her pain may be 
exacerbated by constipation. Alternatively, part of the pain may 
be due to uterine fibroids (seen on CT)/other gynecological 
cause.  Patient has recently had vaginal US and appears to be 
having gyn follow-up although again she has a history of missing 
appointments.   Continued carafate, ranitidine and omeprazole 
and her outpatient pain regimen (Vicodin).  Placed her on bowel 
regimen  but she did not have a BM.  She will have outpatient 
follow-up with GI previously scheduled
.  
# HTN: normotensive.  continued Metoprolol Tartrate 37.5 mg 
PO/NG BID 

.  
# neuropathy:  patient complains of numbness in her legs which 
she attributes to missing her dose of gabapentin.  able to move 
legs normally.  Neurology consulted and recommend workup with 
vit B12, MMA, and SPEP for neuropathy.  Patient has outpatient 
f/u with neurology already scheduled.  Will defer workup to 
outpatient physician. Continue gabapentin.  Will defere vit B12 
to PCP or outpatient neurology. 
.  
# FEN: regular cardiac diet  
# Prophylaxis: heparin SC  
# Access: PIV  
# Code status: presumed full

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Fever.
2. Staphylococcus aureus sepsis (severe blood infection).
3. Drug rash infected with Staph aureus bacteria.
4. Shortness of breath and hypoxia (low oxygen levels).
5. Hypotension (low blood pressure).
6. Congestive heart failure.
7. Breast cancer.
8. Genital herpes.
9. Anemia (low red blood cell count).
10. Abnormal liver function tests.
11. Port pocket infection.
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for for fever.  You developed 
shortness of breath, low oxygen levels, and a fast heart rate.  
During a CT scan, your vital signs and symptoms worsened.  So 
you were transferred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) and 
started on antibiotics for sepsis, a severe infection of the 
blood.  Blood and skin cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus, a 
bacteria known to stick to different parts of the body.  An echo 
of the heart on the skin surface and one internally (TEE) were 
both negative for infections of the heart valves, but did show a 
mild dilation of the right ventricle heart chamber.  Cardiology 
was consulted and they felt that the right ventricle dilation 
was very mild and required no specific therapy.  They did 
recommend changing your blood pressure medicine to metoprolol 
and repeating an echo ___ one month.  While you were ___ the ICU, 
your heart rate became very fast and irregular (atrial 
fibrillation).  This resolved with medication.  Your breathing 
and oxygen levels improved with furosemide (Lasix), a diuretic.  
You should weigh yourself daily to ensure an even fluid balance 
and call your doctors if your ___ increases by more than 5 
lbs or if your ankles become more swollen.  You will need to 
complete a 3 week course of IV antibiotics for the sepsis.  
Although the source of the infection was likely the skin rash, 
your port was removed ___ case the bacteria seeded it and when it 
was removed, it looked like infection may have been present ___ 
the area of the port.  That is why a drain was left ___ place.  
You will need the drain managed by home nurses and the Surgery 
team as an outpatient.  You were also seen by Dermatology, who 
recommended continuing mupiricin ointment for the rash.  Prior 
to going home, you were given trastuzumab (Herceptin) 
chemotherapy for breast cancer.
.
WEIGH YOURSELF DAILY AND CALL A PHYSICIAN FOR WEIGHT GAIN >5 
LBS.
.
YOUR DOCTORS NEED TO ARRANGE A REPEAT ECHO ___ ONE MONTH.  PLEASE 
ENSURE YOU HAVE THIS DONE.
