Discharge Instructions:
PAIN CONTROL:

- You may or may not have had a nerve block depending on the 
type of surgery. This will likely wear off later in the evening 
and it is normal to have increased pain when the nerve block 
wears off. Please take your prescribed pain medications as 
directed with food prior to the nerve block wearing off. 
 - Stay ahead of the pain!
 - Narcotic pain medications can cause constipation. Please take 
a stool softener while taking these and drink plenty of water.
 - Please plan ahead! If you are running out of your medication 
prior to your follow-up appointment please call during business 
hours with a ___ day notice. Prescription refills or changes 
cannot be addressed after normal business hours or on weekends.

NON-NARCOTIC PAIN CONTROL

- Multi-modal pain control is critical. If you are able to take 
Tylenol (acetaminophen) I would strongly encourage you to do so 
according to the instructions on the bottle. Do not take more 
than 4,000 mg of Tylenol in 24 hours.
 - NSAIDs (Advil, Motrin, Aleve, etc) are also excellent for 
pain control post-operatively. Do not take if you have had a 
bone fusion surgery, but for soft tissue procedures or most 
fracture surgeries these medications are acceptable unless you 
are unable to take for other medical reasons or unless we have 
specifically instructed you against it.
 - Elevation with the operative site above the level of the 
heart will decrease swelling and improve pain control
 - Ice or cold therapy may also be helpful. Do not keep ice or 
cold directly on the skin and do not use for more than ___ 
minutes to decrease risk of skin injury from the cold. Do NOT 
use ice when the block is still in effect as you will not know 
if you are injuring yourself. You may place the ice pack behind 
your knee if you have a bulky dressing on your foot. 
 - Every little bit helps. The faster you can come off the 
narcotic medication the better. Most of my patients do not need 
narcotics after the first post-operative visit!

 ACTIVITY:

- You will likely have swelling after surgery. Please keep the 
foot elevated on ___ pillows at all times possible. You can 
apply a dry, covered, ice-bag on top of your dressing or behind 
your knee for 20 minutes at a time as often as you like.
 - Unless instructed otherwise you should not put any weight 
down on your operated extremity until you come back for your 
first postoperative visit.

 CARE FOR YOUR DRESSING:

- Pls perform daily dressing changes to LLE w 
aquaphor/adaptic/xeroform (something non-stick), gauze, webril, 
lightly wrapped ACE
 - It is not unusual to have a little bloody staining through 
your dressing. However please call the office for any concerns.
 - Keep your dressing clean and dry. You will have to cover it 
when you bath or shower. If it gets wet please call the office 
immediately.

 PREVENTION OF BLOOD CLOTS:

- You have been instructed to take medication in order to help 
prevent blood clots after surgery. Please take your warfarin as 
you had been.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Vascular Surgery Service for 
evaluation and treatment.  On ___, the patient emergently 
was taken to the operating room and underwent endovascular 
abdominal aortic aneurysm repair (reader referred to the 
Operative Note for details). The patient was then brought to the 
ICU intubated, sedated, on IV fluids and antibiotics, with a 
foley catheter.  The patient was hemodynamically stable.

Neuro: While intubated, the patient was sedated with propofol. 
Following extubation, the patient received IV dilaudid with good 
effect and adequate pain control.  When tolerating oral intake, 
the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications.

CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. The patient 
was initially hypertensive out of the OR and required 
nitroglycerin drip. Oral agents were started POD2 in the ICU, 
including home carvedilol and oral hydralazine and amlodipine. 
The patient was given PRN doses of IV hydralazine. Following 
transfer to the vascular stepdown unit, the patient did not 
require further IV hydralazine. Lisinopril was held from 
admission given his elevated Cr level. It was restarted as Cr 
trended down on discharge. Amlodipine was discontinued prior to 
discharge when lisinopril was started. The patient will require 
close PCP followup for titration of antihypertensives. ___ will 
be arranged for blood pressure checks. While in the ICU, 
cardiology was consulted for co-management of the patient's CHF. 
There was a slight leak in troponin that was felt to be due to 
demand ischemia and no further troponins were checked after ICU 
stay. In addition, they recommended diuresis when able.

Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirrometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization. Albuterol and ipratropium 
nebs were given as needed.

GI/GU/FEN: Post-operatively, the patient was made NPO with IV 
fluids. OG tube was in place while intubated. Following 
extubation on POD#1, diet was advanced when appropriate, which 
was well tolerated.  Patient's intake and output were closely 
monitored, and IV fluid was adjusted when necessary.  
Electrolytes were routinely followed, and repleted when 
necessary. Creatinine was elevated at admission from baseline 
levels. It was trended postoperatively. The patient was volume 
overloaded postoperatively. IV lasix was administered POD#1 with 
resulting diuresis. However, Cr continued to rise so no further 
lasix was administered. Foley catheter was removed POD#3 and the 
patient subsequently voided without issue. 

ID: The patient's white blood count and fever curves were 
closely watched for signs of infection. Perioperative 
antibiotics were administered.

Endocrine: The patient's blood sugar was monitored throughout 
his stay; insulin dosing was adjusted accordingly. He was 
restarted on oral glycemic agents on discharge.

Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined 
routinely; no transfusions were required.

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay; was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Patient will be seen in followup in 4 weeks time with Dr 
___. At that time, a CTA will be arranged to assess the 
location and function of the stent graft. Patient will also be 
seen by PCP Dr ___ on ___ in followup and for ongoing 
hypertension management.

MEDICATIONS:

     Take Aspirin once daily 

     Do not stop Aspirin unless your Vascular Surgeon instructs 
you to do so. 

     Continue all other medications you were taking before 
surgery, unless otherwise directed

     You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for 
any post procedure pain or discomfort

 

WHAT TO EXPECT AT HOME:

It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:

     Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night

     Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without 
your legs elevated

It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your 
appetite will return with time 

     Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals

     It is important to eat nutritious food options (high 
fiber, lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) 
to maintain your strength and assist in wound healing

     To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

 

ACTIVITIES:

     When you go home, you ___ walk and go up and down stairs

     You ___ shower (let the soapy water run over groin 
incision, rinse and pat dry)

     Your incision ___ be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed

     No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) 
for 1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)

     After 1 week, you ___ resume sexual activity

     After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and 
distance walked as you can tolerate

     No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___

     Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 

     Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours

     New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow 
or green drainage from incisions

     Bleeding from groin puncture site

 

FOR SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site or 
incision)

     Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm 
pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call 
vascular office. If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for 
transfer to closest Emergency Room.

ACTIVE ISSUES

# Hypoxemic respiratory failure: He continued to decompensate 
after transfer, requiring intubation ___. His respiratory 
failure was felt to be caused largely by pulmonary edema, with 
smaller contributions from his ILD and possible HCAP. He 
improved with cardioversion of atrial flutter, diuresis of ~6L, 
and HCAP treatment. He was extubated ___ and by ___ was 
satting in the mid-90s on ___ nasal cannula, consistent with 
his baseline O2 requirement. He continued to sat well on 
low-volume nasal cannula. FYI: Be cautious with supplemental O2. 
Tirate to 92-94%. Patient will become confused if satting too 
much above this level or if he is receiving too much oxygen.

# GI Bleeding: On ___, Pt was noted to have melanotic stools. 
Heparin gtt that had been started for post-cardioversion 
prophylaxis was stopped, and octreotide and pantoprazole drips 
were started. The patient's Hct remained stable. Hepatology was 
consulted and it was felt that the bleeding was likely to to 
known portal gastropathy rather than esophageal varices. On 
___, he had BRBPR and a Hct drop from 27 to 22. He was 
transfused 2U pRBCs and emergent EGD was performed. It showed a 
bleeding ___ tear at GE junction/lesser curvature, 
which was injected w/ 4 cc epinephrine. An adherent clot in 
fundus could not be dislodged. No esophageal varices. He was 
treated with a 7-day course of ceftriaxone as prophylaxis for 
SBP. Repeat EGD was not pursued. His PPI drip was transitioned 
to BID dosing on ___. His Hct remained stable after bleed 
and was stable on discharge.
 
# SHOCK: Multifactorial. Felt mainly due to cardiogenic cause, 
given known AS, EF 30%, pulmonary and lower extremity edema. 
Hypovolemia likely playing a role as well from GI blood loss and 
diuresis. BP in the ___ for most of admission. After GI bleed 
with BRBPR, pt was hypotensive to ___ on norepinephrine. His 
norepinephrine was not able to be weaned even after 
resuscitation w/ 3U pRBCs and ~4L fluids.  Stress-dose steroids 
(50mg solumedrol q6) were empirically started ___ for possible 
adrenal insufficiency, although he was only on 5mg prednisone 
daily prior to admission. His norepinephrine was weaned on ___. 
His stress-dose steroids were tapered and taper should be 
continued post-discharge.

# PAROXYSMAL ATRIAL FIBRILLATION: Noted to be in atrial flutter 
with 2:1 block on admission. It was thought that this arrhythmia 
could have been a major cause of his CHF exacerbation. TEE was 
performed, which showed no clot, so he was cardioverted. 50 J 
initially, went into Afib, then 200 J, went into sinus with 
frequent PACs.
He was started on amiodarone short-term because atrial kick 
critical while in decompensated heart failure. He had one other 
episode of Afib on ___ in the setting of his GI bleed. He was 
initially anticoagulated with heparin gtt after the 
cardioversion, but this was discontinued once melanotic stools 
were noted. His long term plan is for anticoagulation with 
aspirin only.

# ACUTE TOXIC METABOLIC ENCEPHALOPATHY: After intubation, the 
patient was altered for several days, withdrawing to painful 
stimuli but not following commands. Several etiologies were 
considered including slow clearance (due to liver and kidney 
disease) of the sedation given while on the vent, possible 
hepatic encephalopathy, and ICU delirium. He was initially 
treated with lactulose and then rifaximin for hepatic 
encephalopathy. His mental status slowly improved. He continues 
to have issues with confusion on waking and with too high a 
level of supplemental oxygen as above but he typically clears 
quickly.

___ DUE TO ATN: From a baseline Cr 1.0, his Cr peaked at 7.2. 
Renal was consulted and diagnosed ATN from hypotension/poor 
perfusion. His medications were renally-dosed. By discharge his 
Cr improved to 4.6 and was steadily down-trending.

# HCAP:  Resolved. Cultures from BAL with Moraxella, S. pneumo, 
and MSSA. Initially on vancomycin and cefepime (Day ___ = ___, 
switched to levofloquin and nafcillin after speciation. 
Completed 14 day course on ___.

# Steroid-induced hyperglycemia: Carries no diagnosis of 
diabetes. Hgb A1c 8.2% on admission in the setting of chronic 
steroid use. The patient's glycemic control strategy fluctuated 
with nutritional status during this admission. He was given 12U 
glargine plus sliding scale insulin coverage. He will be

Renal U/S: 
FINDINGS:  There is no hydronephrosis seen in either kidney.  
The right kidney measures 12.4 cm, and the left kidney is noted 
to be smaller measuring only 9.4 cm.  A small simple cyst is 
seen in the lateral margin of the right kidney measuring 1.2 x 
1.4 x 1.2 cm.  A small simple cyst is also seen in the 
interpolar region of the left kidney measuring 1.1 x 0.9 cm.  
There is no stone or suspicious solid mass seen in either 
kidney. No perinephric fluid collection is identified.  The 
bladder is moderately distended and is unremarkable in 
appearance. 
  
DOPPLER EXAMINATION:  Color Doppler and spectral waveform 
analysis was 
performed.  Arterial waveforms with normal sharp upstrokes are 
seen in the main renal artery of the right kidney.  Appropriate 
venous flow is seen in the main right renal vein.  Resistive 
indices of the intraparenchymal arteries in the right kidney are 
elevated measuring 0.82-0.89. 
Arterial and venous flow is identified within the left kidney, 
however 
arterial waveforms do not demonstrate any reliable diastolic 
flow. 
IMPRESSION: 
1.  No hydronephrosis.  There are bilateral simple renal cysts 
and the left kidney is noted to be significantly smaller than 
the right kidney. 
2.  No sonographic evidence of renal artery stenosis in the 
right kidney.  The right renal artery stent cannot be visualized 
with ultrasound.  Elevated resistive indices in the right 
kidney, consistent with chronic parenchymal disease.  Arterial 
and venous flow identified in the smaller left kidney; however, 
the arterial waveforms do not demonstrate any diastolic flow. 
Perhaps this is consistent with the reported history that the 
patient's left kidney is not functioning.

___ y.o. F with history of atrial fibrillation, HTN, left breast

.
# Weakness: On admission, Mrs. ___ was treated for presumed 
dehydration in setting of poor PO intake with recent pneumonia.  
CBC and chem-7 showed no evidence of infection.  Chest x-ray 
with no infiltrate.  Orthostatics were negative.  TSH normal, 
ruled out for MI.  Atrial fibrillation noted to be well rate 
controlled.  Recieved 1 liter IVF over first night and felt 
improved.  Physical therapy evlauted and she became tachycardic 
to 140's with ambulation.  Recieved additional 1L NS  and was 
discharged home with home phsical therapy.
.
# History of falls: No true syncope as patient denies LOC.  CT 
head negative.  Physical therapy evaluated and recommended home 
physical therapy.
.
# Shortness of breath: Per patient, at baseline and not 
worsened.  Chest x-ray was normal.  Incentive spirometry for 
presumed atelecatsis.  Did not continue Levofloxacin for last 
day of treatment given no sign of infection.
.
# Atrial fibrillation: CHADS 2 score is 3, and patient should be 
anticoagulated; however given history of falls and allergy to 
aspirin and VWD, she cannot be anticoagulated.  She remained 
rate controlled on telemetry with no hemodynamic instability. 
Continued beta-blocker.
.
# CHF, diastolic, chronic: held lasix given dehydration.  
Recieved IVF per above, restarted lasix on discharge.
.
# Hypothyroidism: TSH WNL, continued levothyroxine at home dose.

PATHOLOGY 
================================================
___: Liver, transjugular biopsy:
1. Established Cirrhosis with prominent sinusoidal fibrosis ( 
confirmed by trichrome stain).
2. Hepatocytes with frequent ballooning degeneration and 
frequent intracytoplasmic hyalin. No significant steatosis.
3. Moderate septal and mild lobular mixed inflammation comprised 
of lymphocytes, neutrophils and histiocytes.
4. Focal area of bile ducts with associated neutrophils.
5. Single large vessel with myxoid changes and intimal edema.
6. Iron stain demonstrates no stainable iron.
Note: The findings are that of established cirrhosis on the 
background of toxic/metabolic injury including Amiodarone. Given 
the presence of neutrophils associated with bile ducts 
additional etiology such as biliary obstruction or sepsis should 
be ruled out. Electron microscopy will be performed and results 
will be issued as an addendum.
Electron Microscopy Addendum (C-___): Fine structural studies 
were performed on formalin fixed, paraffin embedded material, 
yielding morphology that is technically suboptimal and therefore
difficult to examine and interpret. Hepatocytes show glycogen 
granules. No evidence of phospholipidosis ("myelin figures" or 
"zebra bodies") is noted.

Mrs. ___ is a ___ year old woman with ___ recently

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
# Amiodarone- Induced Liver Cirrhosis:
Patient was diagnosed with cirrhosis in ___. Cirrhosis 
is decompensated by recurrent ascites and grade I esophageal 
varices. Unclear etiology at the time of presentation. Patient 
underwent extensive work up for infectious, biochemical causes 
of cirrhosis and ultimately underwent liver biopsy. The findings 
are that of established cirrhosis on the background of 
toxic/metabolic injury including Amiodarone. Electron microscopy 
was done but was technically suboptimal and therefore difficult 
to examine and interpret. No evidence of phospholipidosis 
("myelin figures" or "zebra bodies") is noted (which is seen in 
amiodarone toxicity). Patient maintained no history of alcohol 
use. AFP within normal limits during this hospitalization. Liver 
MRI while in hospital with indeterminate 1.9 cm lesion along the 
inferior medial margin of the liver could reflect a regenerative 
nodule however attention on follow-up imaging is recommended.
- Infection: no known history of SBP, negative on multiple 
diagnostic taps while hospitalized
- Bleed: grade I esophageal varices on EGD ___, not on 
nadolol
- Encephalopathy: alert and oriented x3 throughout 
hospitalization with no known history of encephalopathy

# Recurrent ascites
Patient presented with recurrent ascites over the past several 
weeks. Diagnostic paracentesis done ___ with albumin 1.1 and 
total protein 2.0, with SAAG 2.8 consistent with transudative 
ascites. Given prior history of heart failure with reduced 
ejection fraction, also considered heart failure as potential 
etiology, but found to have recovered EF as described below. 
Ultrasound and liver MRI with no portal vein thrombosis. She was 
initially maintained on oral diuretic but this was discontinued 
due to worsening ___ and concern for HRS as below.  Patient 
underwent ___ paracentesis on ___ of 1900cc fluid. She underwent 
repeat ___ paracentesis on ___ of 340cc. She was maintained on 
low salt diet. No known history of SBP and was negative on 
multiple diagnostic taps.

# ___:
Cr on presentation 1.6, from baseline of 0.9. Notably patient 
had presented to ___ with Cr elevation to 1.7. 
This had initially improved with albumin and volume 
resuscitation to baseline but subsequently worsened with 
diuretic, prompting transfer to ___.  No e/o hydronephrosis on 
renal u/s. Urine studies notable for sodium avid state. Renal 
consulted who noted that her urinary sediment did not show 
granular casts, but did show many hyaline casts indicative of 
low tubular flow, thought to be pre-renal in setting of 
diuresis. She was also noted to have monoclonal IgG lambda on 
SPEP and UPEP, however the quantity was small and unlikely to 
have caused light chain nephropathy. It could, however, have put 
her at risk for ___ with volume depletion. Patient received 
albumin challenge without initial response though notably had 
also undergone contrast study and ~2L paracentesis during this 
time period. Patient managed on escalating doses of octreotide 
and midodrine with initial improvement in blood pressure and 
creatinine to nadir 1.2.  Given low concern for HRS the 
octreotide was discontinued but she was continued on midodrine.  
Upon re-introduction of diuretic patient developed subsequent 
renal injury with creatinine rising to 1.9. She received albumin 
resuscitation. Renal re consulted and urine showed several muddy 
brown casts consistent with ATN and given adequate urine output 
they felt she was safe for discharge home with close follow up 
with PCP. If creatinine does not return to baseline then she 
should be referred to nephrology by her primary care doctor.

# Atrial fibrillation:
Patient has a history of persistent atrial fibrillation, managed 
with amiodarone, metoprolol and rivaroxaban. CHADSVASC 5 based 
on gender, CHF, prior stroke, and CAD. Given concern for 
amiodarone induced liver toxicity, amiodarone was discontinued. 
Anticoagulation initially held given liver biopsy and 
coagulopathy associated with cirrhosis. Rivaroxaban 
contraindicated in class B/C child ___ Cirrhosis. Patient 
started on apixaban but developed worsening coagulopathy with 
rising INR. Hematology consulted who felt that warfarin would 
have better safety profile in setting of severe cirrhosis, ___. 
Patient transitioned to warfarin. She was maintained on stable 
1mg daily dose of warfarin for goal INR ___.  

#Abdominal pain
#Nausea, Vomiting
Patient with intermittent ongoing nausea. Developed worsening 
abdominal pain and nausea/vomiting alongside worsening 
leukocytosis and ___ ___. Started on empiric vancomycin and 
cefepime. Cultures obtained, including peritoneal. Patient also 
underwent imaging workup out of concern for obstruction. CT with 
no intra-abdominal abnormality. Paracentesis performed with no 
evidence of SBP. Given lack of focal source and improving 
symptoms, antibiotics discontinued. 

#Hypoxia
#Productive cough 
Patient developed 2L nasal cannula oxygen requirement during 
hospitalization. CXR obtained on ___, notable for some signs of 
pulmonary edema/ cardiac dysfunction. Atelectasis also felt to 
be component. Diuresis deferred given ongoing ___ as above. 
Hypoxia resolved with incentive spirometry and more aggressive 
physical activity with physical therapy.  
 
# HF with recovered EF:
Patient has a history of heart failure, with previous LVEF 
estimated 20% per OSH records. Repeat TTE while in house notable 
for normal ejection fraction, suggestive of recovered ejection 
fraction. She was initially managed with diuretics but then 
discontinued out of concern for HRS as above. Given low blood 
pressures and ___, home lisinopril held. Patient continued on 
metoprolol while in hospital.

ceftriaxone 1gm Q24H on ___. She completed a three day course of 
ceftriaxone 1gm daily.

syncopal episode. Likely orthostasis in the setting of poor PO 
intake, chronic diarrhea, and vasoplegia from cirrhosis.  No

# Hypoxia/tachypnea:
Overnight on ___, Mrs. ___ developed hypoxia with fever 
to 101.4. DDx includes: CAP, HAP, aspiration PNA, diastolic HF. 
Since beginning presumptive tx for CAP using levofloxacin 750 
Q48h, Mrs. ___ has not spiked a fever. Urine legionella 
antigen and blood cultures negative. Speech and swallow 
evaluated the pt and felt that she was not aspirating to a 
significant degree. They recommended that she was safe to take 
PO pureed solids and thin liquids w/ 1:1 supervision. Initially, 
due to ongoing intermittent hypoxia to 87-88%, she was given 
several doses of furosemide. This did result in increased urine 
output and improvements in her CXR, but due to ___, furosemide 
was discontinued and home lisinopril was held. Renal funcion was 
improving at the time of discharge. She was successfully weaned 
to room air. She will complete a 7 day course of antibiotics for

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with a history of mitral valve and aortic 
valve replacement who presented with worsening dyspnea over 
months and was found to have worsening AI on TTE due to valvular 
leak and planned for outpatient plugging. His hospital course 
was complicated by development of left thigh intramuscular 
hematoma. He was observed and bridged to warfarin. Additionally, 
he was found to have elevated RV impedance and underwent lead 
replacement. 

ACTIVE ISSUES 
=============
# Acute aortic insufficiency 
# Mechanical mitral and aortic vales
# Acute heart failure
Presented with dyspnea requiring BiPap in ED. TTE at OSH showed 
severe 3+ aortic regurgitation. Cardiac surgery and structural 
cardiology were consulted and TEE performed which showed 
moderate aortic regurgitation paravalvularly. Plan was made for 
outpatient percutaneous plugging of paravalvular leak, though 
after discussion with outpatient cardiologist will continue with 
medical optimization for now and defer procedure. Restarted on 
warfarin with heparin bridge while subtherapeutic. D/c INR 2.3, 
D/c Warfarin 5mg, though will require close monitoring.

# Left Thigh Intramuscular Hematoma
Developed acute-onset left thigh pain ___ while walking while 
on heparin gtt bridge awaiting therapeutic INRs. ___ negative 
for DVT. CT with intramuscular hematoma and subcutaneous edema. 
ACS consulted and recommended wrapping leg and holding heparin 
drip. No evidence of compartment syndrome. Heparin initially 
held, then restarted as a bridge to warfarin. INR reached 
therapeutic level and heparin gtt discontinued. Hgb fell, 
transfused for <8, s/p total of 5U pRBC. ACS signed off. 
Hematoma improved substantially prior to discharge. 

# AV block s/p PPM
Patient underwent PPM interrogation and was found to have 
elevated RV lead impedance. He underwent successful lead 
replacement and his PPM was interrogated the next day. Will have 
outpatient device clinic follow=up

# Hyperkalemia
Persistent hyperkalemia throughout admission, requiring 
intermittent treatment with calcium gluconate and 
insulin/dextrose. Etiology felt to be in the setting of 
hemolysis from left thigh hematoma. K was 4.5 on day of DC.

# Leukocytosis
Pt with persistent leukocytosis throughout his admission, 
thought to be stress response ___ hematoma. Infectious w/u was 
negative, though found to have clinically non-significant LLL 
PNA and mild sigmoid diverticulitis incidentally on CT A/P. Had 
brief episode of hypotension and AMS on ___ and was briefly on 
ABx, though BCx were negative and ABx were quickly DC'd

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure treating you for leg swelling/pain, difficulty 
breathing, and chest pain. You received tests in the emergency 
department which showed you were not having a heart attack, and 
a chest x-ray which did not show pneumonia. 

Your difficulty breathing was likely due to your COPD. You were 
treated with albuterol, Advair, and ipratropium/tiotropium, and 
improved. 

Because you were having increased swelling of your legs, tests 
were done to make sure there was no clots in your legs on lungs. 
An ultrasound of your heart did not reveal a definitive cause. 
The swelling may have been triggered by high salt intake or by 
the steroids you were recently taking. Diuretics (water pills) 
help your body remove excess fluid from the body through the 
urine, which helped you to dramatically decrease the swelling in 
your legs. 

It will be very important for you to begin seeing a primary care 
provider ___. They can help manage your pain medications 
as well as your inhalers and diuretics and assess your pain. 
They can also help organize your healthcare for any other 
issues. Building a relationship with a primary care provider 
___ also reduce your need to be hospitalized and be seen in 
emergency departments.

Please see below for an appointment to establish care at ___ 
___, where your insurance is 
accepted. Please take your medications as prescribed. 

We wish you the best,
Your ___ team

nonthyroidal illness as more likely cause. Generally, it is
advisable to obtain TSH and ft4 on the same sample. Patient 
should have repeat thyroid function tests in ___ weeks with

(atrial fibrillation).  This abnormal rhythm can cause strokes, 
so you were started on a blood thinner called Apixaban to 
prevent strokes.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with history of Type II 
diabetes (DMII) complicated by neuropathy, hypertension, 
antiphospholipid antibody syndrome complicated by stroke in 
___, chronic right foot osteomyelitis w/ recent debridement who 
presented with 4d of fatigue, tightness of abdomen and 
increasing lower extremity edema, found to have a heart failure 
exacerbation.
.  
# Acute diastolic heart failure (dCHF): His prior echo in ___ showed LVEF >55% so CHF is likely diastolic in nature. 
Trigger for exacerbation could be medication noncompliance 
leading to volume overload and hypertension, especially since 
the patient admitted that he frequently self-dosed his blood 
pressure medications.  Patchy opacities on CXR were suggestive 
of pneumonia, so pt was treated for this initially with 
levofloxacin, vancomycin, cefepime. Initial cardiac enzymes were 
negative, and pt also had a recent stress test that was 
negative.  PE was also considered given patient's history of 
antiphospholipid syndrome. His WELLS score for PE was 1.5, which 
is a low probability. He had no pleuritic signs or clinical 
symptoms of DVT. Nonetheless, obtained ___ dopplers which were 
neg for DVT bilaterally. Pt was aggressively diuresed with IV 
lasix drip and his pulm edema and oxygenation improved. The 
patchy opacities that were read as possible pneumonia also 
improved, making this diagnosis unlikely. Other infectious work 
up neg, including blood and urine cx and urine legionella ag.  
Antibiotics were stopped on hospital day 4 due to low suspicion 
for pneumonia.  He was maintained on an IV nitroglycerin drip to 
keep his SBP between 110-140 while in the ICU and then 
transitioned to an oral regimen. On discharge, his medication 
regimen consisted of torsemide 20mg daily, lisinopril 40mg 
daily, amlodipine 10mg and carvedilol 12.5mg bid. He was 
continued on ___ 81mg daily and pravastatin 40 mg daily.
.
# Hypertension: pt hypertensive on admission with SBP 160s-170s. 
Patient has not been taking medications for > 3 days.  He was 
placed on nitro drip to keep pressures down. He was restarted on 
his home meds of amlodipine and lisinopril. His atenolol was 
changed to carvedilol for better control of BP as well as beta 
blockade for heart failure.  His medications were titrated as 
needed and on discharge his regimen consisted of torsemide 20mg 
daily, lisinopril 40mg daily, amlodipine 10mg and carvedilol 
12.5mg bid.
.
# Orthostatic hypotension: Patient was orthostatic the last 2 
days of his admission and his creatinine on the day of discharge 
was up to 1.7 from 0.9 on admission.  It was felt that he was 
overdiuresed with torsemide during the admission.  Please 
recheck Cr at follow-up and adjust his dose of torsemide as 
needed to avoid overdiuresis.  
.  
# DMII: Patient w/ longstanding DMII (___), complicated by 
peripheral neuropathy, stroke, gastroparesis, autonomic 
neuropathy. Patient on lantus 52 qhs, and novolog pre-breakfast, 
lunch and dinner. Patient had not been taking insulin for the 
past three days on admission. Glucose level 222 in ED.  He was 
restarted on insulin glargine with insulin humalog sliding scale 
while in house.
.      
# Anti-phospholipid Syndrome: Has history of stroke. INR 
subtherapeutic at 1.4 on admission; had not taken coumadin for 
last 4 days. High risk for thrombus formation, so bridged with 
heparin to coumadin and restarted pt on coumadin and adjusted 
dose as indicated. On discharge, coumadin dose was 7 mg daily 
and INR was 2.7. 
 . 
# Chronic osteomyelitis: Patient was on Keflex PO q6h as 
outpatient, but was started on Cefepime as above for HCAP so 
Keflex was held initially. Due to low suspicion for pneumonia, 
cefepime was stopped and he was placed back on keflex. He 
completed his course prior to discharge.  Has follow-up 
scheduled with ID outpatient.
.

Ms ___ is a ___ year old woman s/p renal transplant in ___ 
with chronic humoral rejection and allograft dysfunction (recent 
creatinine 5.7), chronic anemia, and hypertension who presented 
with increased fatigue and dyspnea, found to have multifocal 
pneumonia and new onset paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, dCHF 
exacerbation and worsening renal function.

#PNA: Ms. ___ initially presented with subjective fevers, 
cough, leukocytosis and tachycardia, as well as CXR with 
bibasilar and right perihilar opacity concerning for infection, 
consistent with pneumonia. Patient was initially started on 
vancomycin/cefepime but was switched to azithromycin and 
ceftriaxone on ___ for more appropriate CAP coverage. Her urine 
Strep pneumo and Legionella were negative for infection, and 
blood cultures were negative to date. She completed azithromycin 
x5d and 5d ceftriaxone. Repeat CXR showed stable opacity. 
Patient was switched to po levofloxacin at discharge for a total 
of 10 day course.

#pAfib with RVR: newly diagnosed this hospitalization, but may 
have been occurring for the past ___ months. CHADS-VASC score =3 
thus may benefit from anticoagulation. Given renal failure, she 
is only a candidate for warfarin, which was held at this time 
pending fistula placement by Transplant surgery. Patient is 
discharged in NSR on 150 mg metoprolol XL BID for rate control. 

#dCHF exacerbation: BNP>70,000 but in setting of CKD and fluid 
overload. Presented with chest pain and increased pulmonary 
edema, but improved with diuresis. Responds to 160 iv lasix, 
receiving it in boluses. TTE ___ w/ worsening dCHF and mild 
regional wall motion abnormality despite flat trops and no 
consistent ECG changes. She was transitioned to home regimen of 
80 mg furosemide BID once near euvolemia.

# Acute on Chronic Kidney Disease: Cr prior to admission 5.7 due 
to chronic transplant humoral rejection and allograft 
dysfunction, with planned outpatient initiation of HD. Of note, 
her diuretics have been increased recently due to worsening 
volume overload, with a rise in her creatinine. Creatinine in 
high 7s range this hospitalization, likely secondary to 
infection. Improved from 7.9 to 7.1 on discharge with treatment 
of infection and with diuresis. For her CKD, patient was 
continued on a calcitriol; sevelamer was also started. Vein 
mapping was completed to facilitate planning for fistula 
placement in the near future.

# S/p Renal transplant with chronic humoral rejection and 
allograft dysfunction: Her home azathioprine was held in the 
setting of acute infection. She was continued on cyclosporine 
and prednisone. Cyclosporine levels were high this 
hospitalization, thus dosing was decreased to 50 mg BID.

# Anemia: Admission H/H of 6.___.4, down from a baseline of 
7.2. Received pRBC transfusions prn for Hgb>7.

# Hypertension: continued home metoprolol, but increased to 150 
mg BID. continued amlodipine

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!

Why were you hospitalized?
- Because you were experiencing fevers and feeling unwell at 
home.

What was done for you this hospitalization?
-You were found to have a pneumonia, for which you received 
antibiotics. You were treated with antibiotics for it through 
the IV. You will need a few more days of oral antibiotics at 
home.
-You developed an abnormal heart rhythm called 'atrial 
fibrillation' or 'afib' while in the hospital with very fast 
heart rates. We managed it by giving you a medication called 
metoprolol (which you take at home) in higher doses. Your heart 
switched back to a normal rhythm by discharge.
-You developed shortness of breath and fluid overload because of 
the stress on your heart with the infection and your chronic 
kidney disease. We gave you more water pills through the iv to 
help you get rid of the fluid. You required oxygen for some 
time, but improved.
-Your kidney function got worse because of the infection you 
were having, but improved a little by the time of discharge with 
water pills and treatment of the infection.
-We did a vein mapping study for when you need to have a fistula 
placed.

What should you do after you leave the hospital?
-Complete your antibiotic course
-Follow up with transplant surgery about placing a fistula.
-We started several more medication that protect the heart which 
you will need to take. 
-You may also need more testing for your heart after you leave 
the hospital.

We wish you the best!

Sincerely,
Your ___ Team

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female with history of stage IV pulmonary sarcoid as 
well as pulmonary hypertension and chronic immunosuppressive 
therapy presenting with worsened dyspnea on exertion in the 
context of stopping her PCP prophylaxis four weeks ago.  

1) Dyspnea on exertion/Hypoxia: Given chest CT most likely 
diagnosis is sarcoid flair. Pulmonary was consulted during this 
admission and performed a bronchoscopy. BAL was PCP negative and 
did not show any bacteria on gram stain. Giver her subacute 
presentation, lack of tachycardia on exam, no EKG changes, and 
improvement with steroids, it was thought that PE was very 
unlikely and the patient did not get a CTA. Patient was treated 
with an increased dose of Prednisone. She will continue of 40mg 
po qday until her pulmonologist instructs her otherwise. She was 
restarted on her Mepron and will continue her outpatient dose of 
methotrexate.  
.  
2) Pulmonary artery hypertension: Patient is currently off 
sildenafil. Recommend outpatient workup for further managment. 
This was not an acute issue during this admission. 
. 
3) Chronic diastolic CHF: Continued patient's daily Lasix. 
.  
4) Osteoarthritis/Chronic knee pain: Continue home tramadol and 
tylenol

The LVEF was mildly decreased at 47% secondary to basal to mid

LVEF was mildly decreased at 45%. There was CMR evidence of

have CAD, decompensated diastolic heart failure and cardiac 
amyloydosis who is currently stable.

elevated troponins (peaked at 0.39) with TWI in V1-V3.  His TTE 
showed global hypokineses and substantially reduced EF compared 
to prior, and evidence of possible infiltration.  He underwent a 
cardiac catheterization on ___ which showed 50% left main 
disease, 50% LAD stenosis, and no intervention was performed at 
this time as evalution for CABG was preferred for the left main 
disease.  Because his cardiac biopsy pathology showed 
amyloydosis a CABG was not appropriate.  Dicussions with 
multiple interventional cardiology attendings discussed whether 
stenting of the left main would be beneficial in this patient. 
It was felt that at this time he would be too high risk to 
undergo PCI of the left main with his possible upcoming 
treatment for his amyloidosis.  This can be further assessed in 
the future with his outpatient cardiologist Dr. ___.

were seen by the hematology/oncologists and they will discuss 
your treatment options as an outpatient when you follow-up with 
them (see below).

called (congestive heart failure). We were taking fluid off by 
give you medications called diuretics (lasix and 
spironolactone). You still have extra fluid on at the time of 
discharge, and will need to have this followed at rehab.
 You were found to have fluid at the base of your lungs (pleural 
effusion), which you have had previously.  You also had excess 
fluid throughout your body.  You were treated with diuretics to 
reduce the fluid overload.  The Pulmonary team again drained 
fluid from your lungs.  Your breathing slowly improved with 
these treatments.  You should follow-up with Pulmonary to 
discuss ways to keep this fluid from returning.

We made multiple changes to you medications while you were here.

ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity is 
moderately dilated. There is an inferobasal left ventricular 
aneurysm. Overall left ventricular systolic function is severely 
depressed (LVEF = 25 %) secondary to severe hypokinesis/akinesis

motion are normal. The aortic valve is not well seen. There is

valve prolapse. Moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The 
estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is 
no pericardial effusion.

ventricular systolic dysfunction; inferobasal aneurysm

Her presenting dyspnea and hypoxia was most likely due to severe 
healthcare-associated pneumonia. She was treated with 
vancomycin/cefepime and later added metronidazole. There was an 
apparent component of pulmonary edema, which resolved with 
furosemide diuresis, although she subsequently developed acute 
renal failure. Prednisone was initially started for possible 
COPD exacerbation. As this seemed clinically unlikely, steroids 
were stopped, although nebulizer treatments were continued for 
wheezing. ACS was ruled out with EKG/trop. She remained hypoxic 
and oxygen dependent, in apparent respiratory distress with 
tachypnea. Due to lack of improvement with above treatments, and 
worsening somnolence, the decision was made with her family 
(son/HCP and daughter-in-law) to focus on comfort measures only. 
All medications not related to comfort, including antibiotics, 
were stopped and morphine concentrated solution was used for 
pain. She is being transferred back to ___, where her 
family feels she will be more comfortable.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Toe down weight bearing left lower extremity, range of motion 
as tolerated at hip

MEDICATIONS:
  1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is 
an over the counter medication.
  2)  Add  tramadol 50-100mg every 6 hours as needed for 
increased pain. Aim to wean off this medication in 1 week or 
sooner.  This is an example on how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
  3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.
  4)  Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of 
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must 
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot 
refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 
  5)  Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you 
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue 
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication 
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over 
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
  6)  Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
  7)  Please take all medications as prescribed by your 
physicians at discharge.
  8)  Continue all home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon.
      
ANTICOAGULATION:
- You are being transitioned to warfarin. It is important to 
have your blood levels ___, PTT, INR) monitored during this 
time, and to set up an appointment with your primary care 
cardiologist Dr. ___ in the next ___ weeks. You are 
taking lovenox 90mg twice a day subcutaneously until your 
warfarin is therapeutic as judged by a INR of 2.0-3.0. You will 
need to follow up with a ___ clinic to track these values 
when you leave the rehab facility. 

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If 
draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper 
tape.
- If you have a splint in place, splint must be left on until 
follow up appointment unless otherwise instructed. Do NOT get 
splint wet.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

Please restart your home medications 

THIS PATIENT IS EXPECTED TO REQUIRE <30 DAYS OF REHAB

levofloxacin.  He initially required BiPAP for respiratory 
support.  Patient improved rapidly on BiPAP, remained afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  His white blood count remained 
within normal limits.  In this setting, antibiotics were 
subsequently stopped given low suspicion for bacterial 
pneumonia. Infectious work up remained negative. This 
presentation was likely multifactorial with possible 
contribution of an aspiration event in the setting of his 
underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and possible 
recurrent flash pulmonary edema.  Speech and swallow was 
consulted and found no overt signs of aspiration.  The patient's 
diet was subsequently advanced with good tolerance. Monitoring 
for possible aspiration following discharge is recommended.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ male with h/o hypertension, type 2 
diabetes, obesity, and venous stasis with recurrent cellulitis 
who presents with shortness of breath and lightheadedness and 
found to have sinus bradycardia with concern for significant 
conduction disease. 
   
# Shortness of breath: Diastolic Heart Failure
The patient presented with new onset exertional dyspnea 
concerning for unstable angina or heart failure. The patient had 
no previous documented history of CAD, but possessed risk 
factors including HTN and DM. Exercise Stress test in ___ in 
setting of a research study revealed fair exercise tolerance w/o 
symptoms, but unable to interpret changes due to LBBB. The 
patient's history, edema, and CXR with note of interstitial 
edema  were highly suggestive of diastolic heart failure. The 
patient was started on IV furosemide with improvement in 
symptoms following diuresis. He was diuresed with Furosemide 
20mg IV daily from ___ and ___ with good response. He was 
then transitioned to oral furosemide at 40mg, on which he was 
discharged. Admission weight was 149.8kg. Discharge weight was 
144.4kg. The patient had a fluid balance of negative five to six 
liters prior to discharge. His renal function remained stable. 
The patient will need to follow up in the outpatient setting to 
re-assess renal function and electrolytes and possibly adjust 
diuretic dose. 

Transthoracic echo during this admission showed LVH, EF>60% , 
and mild mitral regurgitation. No discrete wall motion 
abnormalities were noted, (although due to suboptimal study this 
was not excluded.) The patient was continued on cardioprotective 
regimen of Aspirin 81mg daily and lisinopril 30mg daily. A 
statin was not initiated in the inpatient setting, but the 
patient may benefit from a statin for endothelial protective 
aspects. A beta blocker was not initiated given concern for 
heart block.  The patient will follow up in the outpatient 
setting with his PCP and with cardiology for further management.
.
.  
# Arrythmia:  
On admission the patient was in sinus rhythm, but bradycardic 
with first degree AVB. EKG and telemetry in ED showed evidence 
of 2:1 conduction. With carotid sinus massage bradycardia was 
able to bring out wenchebach AV block. With abulation patient 
had increased heart rate with 1:1 conduction, however, also 
noted  widened QRS/LBBB. This suggested AVN disease and rate 
related LBBB or pause related LBBB. Altogether, this was 
concerning for potentially significant infranodal conduction 
system disease and potential for further decompensation in 
future to third degree heart block. Patient underwent EP study 
on ___ which showed disease in his-bundle system with high risk 
for heart block so a dual chamber pacemaker was placed. The 
patient suffered no complications. He was discharged on a short 
course of prophylactic antibiotics and will follow up in device 
clinic as an outpatient. Of note, the patient uses multiple 
complementary/alternative medicine devices containing magnets 
for the treatment of Diabetic neuropathy. He was informed of the 
dangers of placing a magnet directly over the chest in the area 
of the pacemaker. He was instructed to bring these devices to 
clinic for further assessment.
.  
.  
#  HYPERTENSION
Remained adequately controlled for the majority of his hospital 
course. He was continued on Lisinopril 30 mg daily and started 
on Furosemide 40 mg daily. 
.
#  DIABETES MELLITUS TYPE 2
Patient's A1C was 7.5 in ___. Patient's insulin requirement 
was reduced in the inpatient setting likely reflecting improved 
adherence to diabetic diet. Patient appeared to have poor 
understanding of low simple carb diet and described a distaste 
for artificial sweeteners. Nutrition consult was obtained for 
education regarding diabetic and cardiac diet.  He was 
discharged on his home insulin regimen with instructions to 
monitor blood glucose closely and call MD for BG less than 80 or 
more than 250 for proper insulin titration. 
.  
#  HYPERLIPIDEMIA
LDL on  ___ was 103. ___ 209. TC 175. Patient was not on 
lipid lowering medication upon admission and this was not 
initiated in the inpatient setting. This should be re-addressed 
in the outpatient setting. 
.  
# TINEA CRURIS
Likely related to poorly controlled DM, increased moisture in 
area and obesity. Started on course of Miconazole Powder 2% 1 
Appl TP BID. 
.
# THROMBOCYTOPENIA AND MACROCYTOSIS
Chronic, not far from baseline but etiology unclear. Patient 
denied h/o ETOH abuse, and TSH, B-12, folate were all within 
normal limits. B-12 was noted to be downtrending when comparing 
previous values, thus could consider MMA for confirmation in 
outpatient setting. Values remained stable/ within baseline 
throughout hospital course. 
.
# OSA
He was continued on nocturnal C-PAP.
.
# Weight gain with subjective increase in abdominal girth
Given imprecise exam with patient's body habitus difficult to 
assess.  Laboratory studies revealed normal albumin and no 
significant proteinuria to suggest nephrotic syndrome. Abdominal 
ultrasound was obtained which revealed no underlying ascites.   
Patient feels some improvement with diuresis. Overall, felt 
likely secondary to generalized fluid retention in the setting 
of diastolic heart failure. Patient noted some improvement with 
diuresis. (see above)
.
# Conjunctival erythema and tearing
Patient complained of eye tearing and redness without pruritus 
or purulent dishcarge. Exam without findings concerning for 
infectious conjunctivitis and symptoms felt likely secondary to 
non-specific irriation due to dryness. Patient given artificial 
Tears to be used as needed.
.  
TRANSITION OF CARE
- follow up with PCP for management of DM, HTN, evaluation of 
thrombocytopenia/ macrocytosis, tinea cruris. He will also need 
f/u labs given initiation of diuretic.
- follow up with cardiology for management of diastolic heart 
failure
- follow up with electrophysiology in device clinic
- maintained full code status throughout hospital course.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr ___,

You were admitted to the hospital for low heart rate and 
shortness of breath.  We were concerned that you had a problem 
with the conduction system in your heart that might cause 
abnormal heart rhythms or cause your heart to stop beating. We 
did a procedure to test for this and found significant disease 
in your conduction system that made us worried about the 
possibility of your heart stopping suddenly, so a pacemaker was 
placed. You will need to follow up in device clinic to have this 
checked. Please remember to bring with you all products 
containing magnets so they can be assessed; and please remember 
never to place a magnet over your chest in the area of the 
pacemaker, as this can cause the device to stop working.

You were also found to have some fluid overload. This is because 
your heart muscles are very stiff and are causing blood to back 
up in the lungs and in your legs (diastolic heart failure). We 
treated you with a diurectic, Furosemide (Lasix), and you 
improved. It is important to continue taking this medication to 
prevent fluid from building up. You will need to follow up with 
your doctor once you leave to check labs and to adjust your 
dose. You will also need to see a cardiologist for further 
evaluation of heart failure. It is also important to lose weight 
and control your blood pressure and diabetes, as all of these 
affect your heart.

While you were here you required less insulin than you were on 
before. This is probably because your diet in the hospital had 
less sugar. Please continue to check your blood sugars 
frequently once you leave and call your doctor if your blood 
sugar is less than 80 or more than 250 so that appropriate 
adjustments to your insulin can be made.

Medication changes
START Furosemide (diuretic)
START Miconazole Powder 2% (for skin fungal infection)
START Cephalexin (antibiotic to prevent infection in pacemaker)

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was our pleasure caring for you at ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital with 
shortness of breath.  We found that this was due to a 
combination of pneumonia, a flare of your COPD, and too much 
fluid in your lungs.  The pneumonia may have been due to food 
going down the wrong pipe (a condition called "aspiration"), for 
which our speech language pathologists recommended a modified 
diet for you.  You will get your swallowing function re-tested 
in the future and your diet will be advanced as you are able to 
tolerate.

We also found that you have a new diagnosis of congestive heart 
failure.  This caused too much fluid to accumulate in your lungs 
and in your legs.  We gave you medications to remove this fluid; 
gradually, the amount of swelling in your legs decreased.  Also 
while you were here, your kidney function was temporarily 
decreased, but it recovered back to its previous level.

Finally, you had difficulty emptying your bladder, so a catheter 
was placed in your bladder to help you urinate.  This should be 
removed in the next several days.   

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted and taken to the operating room on 
___ where he underwent a coronary artery bypass graft x5. 
Please see operative note for surgical details. In summary he 
had: 1.  Coronary artery bypass graft x 5, four arterial grafts 
using bilateral internal mammary arteries and one long saphenous 
vein graft.
2.  Skeletonized left internal mammary artery to left anterior 
descending artery.
3.  Skeletonized free right internal mammary artery sequential 
grafting to the ramus, ramus 2 and obtuse marginal arteries.
4.  Long saphenous vein graft to posterior left ventricular 
branch.
5.  Endoscopic harvesting of the long saphenous vein.
He tolerated the surgery well and post-operatively he was taken 
to the CVICU for invasive monitoring in stable condition. ICU 
course was complicated by prolonged intubation due secretions, 
and hypoxia. He failed trial extubation due to inability to 
manage his secretions and was reintubated. He then was 
aggressively diuresed with Lasix infusion. He was febrile and 
started on empiric antibiotics for possible PNA, however 
cultures were negative and antibx were stopped. Due to prolonged 
intubation, tube feedings were initiated via a dobhoff tube. 
Once extubated successfully on POD#9, he was delirious, 
agitation, and confusion and was managed with Ativan prn. Of 
note, he was taking Clonazepam at home prior to admission. He 
was evaluated by psychiatry per his family's request. Psychiatry 
recommended stopping clonazepam, adequately treating pain and 
giving consistent messages regarding plan of care. By the time 
of discharge his delirium was significantly improved.  
 His hospital course was further complicated by acute kidney 
injury and hypernatremia. At the time of discharge his creat was 
trending back toward baseline, his sodium remained elevated and 
he was receiving free water via dophoff tube. He was noted to 
cough with liquids. He was evaluated by speech and swallow team 
and the following was recommended: nectar thick liquids and 
pureed solids and meds crushed in apple sauce. 1:1 supervision. 
His chest tubes and pacing wires were removed per cardiac 
surgery protocol without complication. On POD 10 he was 
transferred to the stepdown floor for continued care and 
recovery. He worked with nursing and physical therapy to 
increase his strength and conditioning.  
 Physical therapy recommended a short stay at rehabilitation 
upon discharge. On POD#16 he was transferred to ___ 
___ in ___ in stable condition. All appointments and 
instructions were advised and provided to the rehab facility.
